     271             : static a_ref_entry_ptr alloc_ref_entry(a_symbol_ptr            sym_ptr,
     272             :                                        a_source_position       *pos)
     273             : /*
     274             : Allocate a reference entry and return a pointer to it.  The information
     275             : provided (kind of expression, symbol pointer, and location of reference) is
     276             : placed in the entry.  At this point the kind of reference is the generic
     277             : SRK_REFERENCE.  An entry of this kind is used to hold information on a single
     278             : reference to a symbol in an expression.  The information is held, rather than
     279             : recorded immediately, because the kind of reference may be revised as more of
     280             : the expression is scanned.  The entry is put on the reference list for
     281             : the current expression, headed by curr_expr_ref_entries.
     282             : */
     283             : {
     284             :   a_ref_entry_ptr rep;
     285             : 
     286             :   if (avail_ref_entries != NULL) {
     287             :     /* Reuse a previously-freed entry. */
     288             :     rep = avail_ref_entries;
     289             :     avail_ref_entries = rep->next;
     290             :   } else {
     291             :     /* Allocate a new entry. */
     292             :     rep = (a_ref_entry_ptr)alloc_fe(sizeof(a_ref_entry));
     293             : #if DEBUG
     294             :     num_ref_entries_allocated++;
     295             : #endif /* DEBUG */
     296             :   }  /* if */
     297             :   rep->kind = SRK_REFERENCE;
     298             :   if (expr_stack->is_default_arg_expression) {
     299             :     rep->kind |= SRK_DEFAULT_ARG_EXPR;
     300             :   }  /* if */
     301             :   rep->already_recorded = FALSE;
     302             : #if CHECKING
     303             :   rep->freed = FALSE;
     304             : #endif /* CHECKING */

     311             :     /* Remember the current associated IL entry for a pack element. */
     312             :     rep->specific_il_entry = source_corresp_entry_for_symbol(sym_ptr);

     315             :      The list is dumped when flush_ref_entries_list is called.
     316             :      The entry is put at the end of the list to preserve source order. */

     436      611831 : void flush_ref_entries_except(a_ref_entry_ptr keep_list1,
     437             :                               a_ref_entry_ptr keep_list2)

     439             : Look for reference entries on the curr_expr_ref_entries list that are not
     440             : also on either of the keep_list1 or keep_list2 lists.  For each such entry,
     441             : record the indicated reference and free the entry.  This is used at the

     443             : up to the caller and therefore cannot be modified further.

     488             : 
     489      110875 : a_ref_entry_ptr ref_entry(a_symbol_ptr      sym_ptr,
     490             :                           a_source_position *source_position)
     491             : /*
     492             : Allocate a reference entry for a reference to the symbol sym_ptr
     493             : at position source_position, put the entry on the list of entries for
     494             : the current expression, and return a pointer to it.  This is needed when
     495             : the kind of reference is not known yet because it can be affected by
     496             : context.  When the proper reference kind has been determined, the entry
     497             : will be updated, and the reference will be recorded when the entry is
     498             : freed.  If the proper kind of reference is known right away, it is
     499             : recorded right away and no entry is created; NULL is returned.
     500             : */
     501             : {
     502      110875 :   a_ref_entry_ptr rep;
     503      110875 :   a_boolean       ref_kind_can_be_affected_by_context = FALSE;
     504      110875 :   a_boolean       evaluated = curr_expr_is_potentially_evaluated();
     505      110875 :   a_symbol_ptr    fund_sym = fundamental_symbol_of(sym_ptr);
     506             : 
     507      110875 :   if (sym_ptr->ambiguous) {

     564       10566 : static void f_check_address_taken_ref(a_ref_entry_ptr rep)
     565             : /*
     566             : The reference entry pointed to by rep includes an address-taken
     567             : reference.  Check to see if the symbol in the reference can have its
     568             : address taken, and if not issue an error.
     569             : */
     570             : {
     571       10566 :   a_symbol_ptr sym = rep->symbol;
     572             : 
     573             :   /* Note that this routine is not the right place to set the address_taken
     574             :      flag in routines, because not all references that are address-taken
     575             :      initially stay that way.  See the comment for variables below. */
     576             :   /* The only possible error cases are variables, and only register variables
     577             :      at that.  Functions can always have their addresses taken.  Also
     578             :      static data members (they cannot be "register"). */
     579       10566 :   if (sym->kind == (a_symbol_kind)sk_variable) {
     580        1882 :     a_variable_ptr var = sym->variant.variable.ptr;
     581        1882 :     if (C_mode() &&
     582         641 :         (var->storage_class == (a_storage_class)sc_register
     583             : #if NAMED_REGISTERS_ALLOWED
     584         641 :          || var->has_named_register_storage_class
     585             : #endif /* NAMED_REGISTERS_ALLOWED */
     586             :                                              )) {
     587             :       /* Cannot take the address of a register variable in C (this includes
     588             :          variables with named-register storage class in Embedded C).  For
     589             :          ordinary register variables, this is allowed in C++, and is allowed
     590             :          (with a warning) in C (except in strict error mode).  For named
     591             :          registers, a strict error is always issued. */
     592           0 :       if (
     593             : #if NAMED_REGISTERS_ALLOWED
     594           0 :           !var->has_named_register_storage_class &&
     595             : #endif /* NAMED_REGISTERS_ALLOWED */
     596           0 :           (SVR4_C_mode || strict_ansi_error_severity != es_error)) {
     597           0 :         expr_pos_warning(ec_address_of_register_variable, &rep->position);
     598             :       } else {
     599           0 :         expr_pos_error(ec_address_of_register_variable, &rep->position);
     600             :         /* Turn the reference into an error reference so that the error will
     601             :            be issued only once. */
     602           0 :         rep->kind = (rep->kind & ~SRK_ALL_REFERENCES) | SRK_ERROR;
     603           0 :         rep->already_recorded = FALSE;
     604             :       }  /* if */
     605             :     }  /* if */
     606             :     /* Indicate that the address of the variable has been taken.  Setting
     607             :        the flag here means it is set even for cases where an address
     608             :        is used at some intermediate step but doesn't escape, e.g.,
     609             :          a[2] = 1;  // address_taken on "a"
     610             :        but a simple interpretation of address_taken seems to be what
     611             :        people prefer.  Note that the flag is also set when the
     612             :        reference is recorded later, but only if the address-taken
     613             :        reference survives to that point, so the setting there is
     614             :        more discriminating.  One can remove the assignment here to
     615             :        get the other interpretation.  If one does so, one should
     616             :        consider whether one wants register variables and parameters
     617             :        treated in some special way (e.g., one might want to set the
     618             :        address_taken flag here anyway for those), since the address_taken
     619             :        flag might be used to decide whether to allocate storage
     620             :        for those variables. */
     621        1882 :     set_variable_address_taken(var);
     622        8684 :   } else if (sym->kind == (a_symbol_kind)sk_static_data_member) {
     623             :     /* For simple interpretation of address_taken, set address_taken
     624             :        on static data members here.  This can be removed.  See comments
     625             :        above. */
     626           0 :     set_variable_address_taken(sym->variant.static_data_member.variable);
     627        8684 :   } else if (sym->kind == (a_symbol_kind)sk_field) {
     628             :     /* For anonymous union fields, if the field belongs to an unnamed
     629             :        anonymous union variable, set the address_taken field on that
     630             :        variable.  Walk up the list of anonymous_parent_objects until we
     631             :        get to a variable, if any.  Only in C++.  This can be removed.
     632             :        See comments above. */

     634         862 :     while (sym_apo != NULL) {
     635         240 :       if (sym_apo->kind == (a_symbol_kind)sk_variable) {
     636           0 :         set_variable_address_taken(sym_apo->variant.variable.ptr);
     637           0 :         break;

     656      113972 : void change_ref_kinds(a_ref_entry_ptr         ref_list,
     657             :                       a_symbol_reference_kind new_kind)

     670       40400 :     if (old_kind & SRK_ERROR) {
     671             :       /* An error reference is never changed to something else. */

     673             :       /* For some cases, the old kind of reference is put out before the new
     674             :          kind is set.  That's necessary, for example, in
     675             :            void f(int &);
     676             :            int j;

     678             :              f(j = 1);  // Modification gets replaced by address taken
     679             :            }
     680             :          One really wants both kinds of references.  A similar case is
     681             :              (j = k)++;
     682             :          One wants to record the modification separately and before the
     683             :          use of the value to avoid a diagnostic about using the variable
     684             :          before it is set. */
     685       40400 :       if ((old_kind & SRK_MODIFICATION) &&
     686          24 :           (new_kind & (SRK_ADDRESS_TAKEN | SRK_USE))) {
     687           0 :         record_reference(rep);
     688             :       }  /* if */
     689             :       /* Set the new reference kind. Turn off all old bits, then turn on
     690             :          new bits.  SRK_REFERENCE remains set in all cases. */
     691       40400 :       rep->kind = (old_kind & ~SRK_ALL_REFERENCES) | new_kind;

     693             :       /* If the reference kinds include address-taken, check for errors
     694             :          related to that. */
     695       40400 :       check_address_taken_ref(rep);

     967       54982 : an_init_component_ptr alloc_init_component(an_init_component_kind kind)
     968             : /*

     970             : kind to "kind" and its fields to default values, and return a pointer to it.

    1340           0 : void add_operand_to_initializer_cache(an_operand           *operand,

    1397        6259 : void extract_operand_from_expression_component(an_init_component_ptr icp,

    1399             :                                                a_boolean             free_icp)
    1400             : /*

    1402             : return it in *operand.  Free icp if free_icp is TRUE.  Aside from
    1403             : copying the operand, this does whatever other processing might be
    1404             : needed to unbundle the operand.

    1407        6259 :   an_operand *icp_operand;

    1414        6259 :   unbundle_init_component_expressions(icp);

    1418             :        the returned operand). */
    1419           0 :     icp_operand->ref_entries_list = NULL;
    1420           0 :     change_to_error_operand(icp_operand);
    1421           0 :     free_init_component_list(icp);
    1422             :   }  /* if */
    1423        6259 : }  /* extract_operand_from_expression_component */

    1425             : 
    1426           0 : a_boolean fetch_operand_from_initializer_cache(an_operand           *operand,
    1427             :                                                an_initializer_cache *cache)
    1428             : /*
    1429             : Remove the first expression from the indicated initializer cache,
    1430             : return it in *operand, and return TRUE.  Free the init-component entry
    1431             : removed from the cache.  If there is no cache (cache == NULL) or the
    1432             : cache is empty, return FALSE.  If the entity removed from the cache is
    1433             : a braced-init-list, issue an error and return an error operand.
    1434             : If the expression is bundled, unbundle it; the current lifetime on
    1435             : the expression stack is discarded in that case.  That implies that
    1436             : this routine must be called after the expression stack has been
    1437             : pushed.
    1438             : */
    1439             : {
    1440           0 :   a_boolean             result = FALSE;
    1441           0 :   an_init_component_ptr icp;
    1442             :

    1444           0 :   if (icp != NULL) {
    1445           0 :     result = TRUE;
    1446           0 :     extract_operand_from_expression_component(icp, operand, /*free_icp=*/TRUE);
    1447             :   }  /* if */
    1448           0 :   return result;
    1449             : }  /* fetch_operand_from_initializer_cache */
    1450             :

    1630       32232 : void transfer_context_from_enclosing_expr_stack_entry(
    1631             :                                                 a_boolean           direct,
    1632             :                                                 an_expr_stack_entry *old_entry,
    1633             :                                                 an_expr_stack_entry *new_entry)
    1634             : /*
    1635             : The entry new_entry is being pushed onto the expression stack, and old_entry
    1636             : is the enclosing stack entry.  Transfer any context flags from the old to the
    1637             : new entry.  For example, if the old entry is marked as inside a default
    1638             : argument expression, the new entry is so marked as well.  If direct is TRUE,
    1639             : this is being done for a normal push of one entry an top of another.
    1640             : If it is FALSE, the connection is less direct; e.g., we went from expression
    1641             : processing to declaration processing and back to expression processing again,
    1642             : as in a decltype.
    1643             : */
    1644             : {
    1645       32232 :   check_assertion(old_entry != NULL);
    1646             :   /* is_template_arg_expression is not copied down, because it indicates the
    1647             :      top level in a template argument expression.  Likewise for
    1648             :      is_vla_dimension_expression.
    1649             :      in_cctor_elision_initializer is also not copied down; nested expressions
    1650             :      in an elision initializer are not subject to the optimization. */
    1651       32232 :   new_entry->is_default_arg_expression = old_entry->is_default_arg_expression;
    1652             : #if MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED
    1653             :   new_entry->is_cli_attr_arg_expression =
    1654             :                                         old_entry->is_cli_attr_arg_expression;

    1659             : #if GNU_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED
    1660       32232 :   new_entry->marked_as_gnu_extension |= old_entry->marked_as_gnu_extension;
    1661             : #endif /* GNU_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED */
    1662       32232 :   if (direct) {
    1663       32223 :     new_entry->evaluated = old_entry->evaluated;
    1664       32223 :     new_entry->potentially_evaluated = old_entry->potentially_evaluated;
    1665       32223 :     new_entry->is_type_operator_arg_expression =
    1666       32223 :                                    old_entry->is_type_operator_arg_expression;

    1677             : 
    1678      243383 : void push_expr_stack(an_expression_kind      expression_kind,
    1679             :                      an_expr_stack_entry_ptr new_entry,
    1680             :                      a_boolean               force_object_lifetime,
    1681             :                      a_boolean               suppress_object_lifetime)
    1682             : /*
    1683             : Push a new entry on the top of the expr_stack.  expression_kind indicates
    1684             : the kind of the expression.  new_entry is used as the new top-of-stack
    1685             : entry (the entries are local variables on the stack).  This is done
    1686             : at the start of a major expression.  An object lifetime is pushed
    1687             : if necessary for a full expression; that's forced by force_object_lifetime
    1688             : TRUE (which is used to say that even if temporaries have lifetime to
    1689             : end-of-scope, this expression's temporaries need to be destroyed at
    1690             : the end of the expression, e.g., because it's an expression repeated
    1691             : in a loop).  If suppress_object_lifetime is TRUE, no object lifetime
    1692             : is pushed regardless of any of the other factors.
    1693             : */
    1694             : {
    1695             :   /* A "full expression" is one not inside another expression.  That's
    1696             :      significant for the lifetime of temporaries. */
    1697      243383 :   a_boolean full_expr = (expr_stack == NULL);
    1698             : 
    1699      243383 :   new_entry->prev = expr_stack;
    1700      243383 :   new_entry->expression_kind = expression_kind;

    1702      243383 :   curr_expr_ref_entries = NULL;

    1838             : 
    1839         174 : void undo_side_effects_for_discarded_unevaluated_expression(void)
    1840             : /*
    1841             : The expression associated with the current level of the expression stack
    1842             : is unevaluated and is being discarded.  Undo any global side effects like
    1843             : additions to the source sequence list (such things can happen because
    1844             : of GNU statement expressions in the expression).
    1845             : */
    1846             : {
    1847         174 :   a_scope_stack_entry_ptr ssep = &scope_stack_top();
    1848             : 
    1849         174 :   check_assertion(expr_stack != NULL &&
    1850             :                   curr_expr_kind_is(ek_sizeof) &&
    1851             :                   !expr_stack->potentially_evaluated);
    1852         174 :   ssep->last_scope = expr_stack->last_subscope_preceding_expr;
    1853         174 :   if (ssep->last_scope == NULL) {
    1854         174 :     ssep->first_scope = NULL;
    1855             :   } else {
    1856           0 :     ssep->last_scope->next = NULL;
    1857             :   }  /* if */
    1858             : #if GENERATE_SOURCE_SEQUENCE_LISTS
    1859         174 :   { a_source_sequence_entry_ptr  ss_list, ss_ptr, ss_list_end;
    1860         174 :     ss_ptr = expr_stack->last_source_seq_entry_preceding_expr;
    1861         174 :     if (ss_ptr != NULL && ss_ptr->next != NULL) {
    1862           0 :       ss_list_end = ssep->end_of_source_sequence_list;
    1863           0 :       ss_list = ss_ptr->next;
    1864           0 :       ssep->end_of_source_sequence_list = ss_ptr;
    1865           0 :       if (ssep->end_of_source_sequence_list == NULL) {
    1866             :         ssep->source_sequence_list = NULL;
    1867             :       } else {
    1868           0 :         ssep->end_of_source_sequence_list->next = NULL;
    1869             :       }  /* if */
    1870             :       /* Traverse the dropped source sequence entries and ensure that no entry
    1871             :          representing a type declaration points back to the dropped entry. */
    1872           0 :       for (ss_ptr = ss_list; ss_ptr != NULL; ss_ptr = ss_ptr->next) {
    1873           0 :         if (ss_entry_kind(ss_ptr) ==
    1874             :                                (an_il_entry_kind)iek_src_seq_secondary_decl) {

    1894             : 
    1895      243383 : void pop_expr_stack(void)
    1896             : /*
    1897             : Pop the top entry off the expr_stack.  This is done at the end of a
    1898             : major expression.
    1899             : */

    1901      243383 :   an_expr_stack_entry_ptr new_top;

    1903      243383 :   if (expr_stack->lifetime != NULL) {

    1909             :          were issued). */

    1911             :     }  /* if */
    1912       48048 :     (void)pop_object_lifetime();
    1913             :   }  /* if */

    1915      243383 :   flush_ref_entries_list();

    1917      243383 :   curr_expr_ref_entries = expr_stack->old_ref_entries_list;

    1919        3936 :       !expr_stack->potentially_evaluated &&
    1920        3936 :       !expr_stack->unevaluated_expr_will_be_kept_in_il) {
    1921         174 :     undo_side_effects_for_discarded_unevaluated_expression();

    1942             :   /* Pop the stack. */
    1943      243383 :   expr_stack = new_top;

    2016             : 
    2017      201753 : void rule_out_expr_kinds(a_ruled_out_expr_kind_set ruled_out_set,
    2018             :                          an_operand                *operand)
    2019             : /*
    2020             : Set flags in the operand "operand" indicating that the kinds of expressions
    2021             : indicated by the bit set ruled_out_set are ruled out, meaning that
    2022             : constructs have appeared in the expression that are not allowed to
    2023             : appear in the ruled-out kinds of expressions.  This is not an error;
    2024             : we're just keeping track so that we can ask later if the expression
    2025             : qualifies as, for example, an integral constant expression.
    2026             : This mechanism is not used in C++11 mode.
    2027             : */
    2028             : {
    2029             :   /* These flags are not maintained in C++11 mode.  There, we only care
    2030             :      whether an entire expression is constant, not about subexpressions.
    2031             :      If an unevaluated operand of a "?" doesn't have the form of a constant
    2032             :      in C++11 mode, for example, that's fine; the overall expression
    2033             :      can still be constant. */
    2034      201753 :   if (!constexpr_enabled) {
    2035       14626 :     if (ruled_out_set & ROEK_CONSTANT) {
    2036             :       /* Record the fact that the entire current expression is nonconstant. */
    2037        9099 :       expr_stack->constant_expr_ruled_out = TRUE;
    2038             :       /* If a constant expression is ruled out, an integral constant
    2039             :          expression is ruled out also. */
    2040        9099 :       ruled_out_set |= ROEK_INTEGRAL_CONSTANT;
    2041             :     }  /* if */
    2042       14626 :     operand->ruled_out_expr_kinds |= ruled_out_set;
    2043             :   }  /* if */
    2044      201753 : }  /* rule_out_expr_kinds */
    2045             : 
    2046             : #if SEQUENCING_DIAGNOSTICS_ENABLED
    2047             : 
    2048             : static void issue_sequencing_diagnostic(a_seq_pt_info_entry_ptr spiep)
    2049             : /*
    2050             : If a sequencing diagnostic hasn't been previously emitted, emit one now.
    2051             : Typically, the same diagnostic is issued multiple times in the same expression
    2052             : (once for each unsequenced side-effect or use).
    2053             : */
    2054             : {
    2055             :   if (!spiep->diagnostic_issued) {
    2056             :     if (expr_diagnostic_should_be_issued(es_remark,
    2057             :                                          ec_unsequenced_use_of_variable)) {
    2058             :       check_assertion(is_variable_node(spiep->expr));

    2066             : 
    2067             : 
    2068             : static a_seq_pt_info_entry_ptr check_for_unsequenced_uses(
    2069             :                                           a_seq_pt_info_entry_ptr side_effects,
    2070             :                                           a_seq_pt_info_entry_ptr uses)
    2071             : /*
    2072             : Issue diagnostics for every case where there's a side-effect and a use.
    2073             : Returns a pointer to the last "use" on the list of uses.
    2074             : */
    2075             : {
    2076             :   a_seq_pt_info_entry_ptr effect, use, result = NULL;
    2077             : 
    2078             :   for (use = uses; use != NULL; use = use->next) {
    2079             :     for (effect = side_effects; effect != NULL; effect = effect->next) {
    2080             :       issue_sequencing_diagnostic(effect);
    2081             :       issue_sequencing_diagnostic(use);
    2082             :     }  /* for */
    2083             :     result = use;
    2084             :   }  /* for */
    2085             :   return result;
    2086             : }  /* check_for_unsequenced_uses */
    2087             : 
    2088             : 
    2089             : static void complete_outstanding_side_effects(
    2090             :                                             a_seq_pt_var_entry_ptr spvep,
    2091             :                                             a_boolean              entire_list)
    2092             : /*
    2093             : A sequencing operation has occurred that forces completion of all side-effects;
    2094             : reset those side-effects that are independent of value computation.  If
    2095             : entire_list is TRUE, process all entries on spvep; otherwise just operate
    2096             : on spvep itself.
    2097             : */
    2098             : {
    2099             :   a_seq_pt_info_entry_ptr se;
    2100             : 
    2101             :   for (; spvep != NULL; spvep = spvep->next) {
    2102             :     for (se = spvep->side_effects; se != NULL; se = se->next) {
    2103             :       if (se->independent_of_value_computation) {
    2104             :         se->independent_of_value_computation = FALSE;
    2105             :       }  /* if */
    2106             :     }  /* for */
    2107             :     if (!entire_list) break;
    2108             :   }  /* for */
    2109             : }  /* complete_outstanding_side_effects */
    2110             : 
    2111             : 
    2112             : static void merge_seq_pt_info_lists(a_seq_pt_var_entry_ptr lspvep,
    2113             :                                     a_seq_pt_var_entry_ptr rspvep,
    2114             :                                     a_boolean              sequenced,
    2115             :                                     a_boolean              is_assignment)
    2116             : /*
    2117             : This routine merges two sets of sequencing information pertaining to the
    2118             : same variable.  Items are moved from rspvep to lspvep (so that rspvep
    2119             : is effectively empty on return).  When sequenced is TRUE, all of the
    2120             : side-effects and uses in lspvep occur before any side-effect or use in
    2121             : rspvep, so no sequencing diagnostics are generated.  When sequenced is
    2122             : FALSE, a sequencing diagnostic is issued if a side-effect in one list
    2123             : is found with either a side-effect or a use on the other list.  When
    2124             : is_assignment is TRUE, the side-effect in rspvep represents the modification
    2125             : of object in an assignment expression.
    2126             : */
    2127             : {
    2128             :   a_seq_pt_info_entry_ptr se1, se2, use, last = NULL;
    2129             : 
    2130             :   check_assertion(lspvep->variable == rspvep->variable);
    2131             :   if (lspvep->side_effects == NULL) {
    2132             :     /* No side-effects in the first expression; the resulting list is
    2133             :        whatever is in the second expression. */
    2134             :     lspvep->side_effects = rspvep->side_effects;
    2135             :   } else if (rspvep->side_effects == NULL) {
    2136             :     /* No side-effects in the second expression; reset the
    2137             :        independent_of_value_computation flag on all side-effects in the
    2138             :        first expression (e.g., a case like "(x++, x)" where the post-increment
    2139             :        side-effect has been sequenced). */
    2140             :     if (sequenced) {
    2141             :       complete_outstanding_side_effects(lspvep, /*entire_list=*/FALSE);
    2142             :     }  /* if */
    2143             :   } else {
    2144             :     /* Both expressions have side-effects on the same variable. */
    2145             :     if (is_assignment) {
    2146             :       /* In this case we're adding the side-effect for an assignment
    2147             :          expression; the side-effect is sequenced after the value computation
    2148             :          of both of the operands (lspvep reflects the merged lists of both
    2149             :          right and left operands of the assignment expression).  Only
    2150             :          side-effects that are unaffected by value computation will conflict
    2151             :          with this new side-effect (e.g., "x = ++x" is okay, but "x = x++" is
    2152             :          unsequenced). */
    2153             :       check_assertion(rspvep->side_effects->next == NULL);
    2154             :       for (se1 = lspvep->side_effects; se1 != NULL; se1 = se1->next) {
    2155             :         if (se1->independent_of_value_computation) {
    2156             :           issue_sequencing_diagnostic(se1);
    2157             :           issue_sequencing_diagnostic(rspvep->side_effects);
    2158             :         }  /* if */
    2159             :       }  /* for */
    2160             :       last = rspvep->side_effects;
    2161             :     } else {
    2162             :       if (sequenced) {
    2163             :         complete_outstanding_side_effects(lspvep, /*entire_list=*/FALSE);
    2164             :       } else {
    2165             :         for (se1 = lspvep->side_effects; se1 != NULL; se1 = se1->next) {
    2166             :           /* This un-sequenced side-effect must conflict with at least one
    2167             :              other side-effect, so issue a diagnostic. */
    2168             :           issue_sequencing_diagnostic(se1);
    2169             :         }  /* for */
    2170             :       }  /* if */
    2171             :       for (se2 = rspvep->side_effects; se2 != NULL; se2 = se2->next) {
    2172             :         if (!sequenced) {
    2173             :           issue_sequencing_diagnostic(se2);
    2174             :         }  /* if */
    2175             :         last = se2;
    2176             :       }  /* for */
    2177             :     }  /* if */
    2178             :   }  /* if */
    2179             :   if (last != NULL) {
    2180             :     /* Merge the two lists of side-effects. */
    2181             :     last->next = lspvep->side_effects;
    2182             :     lspvep->side_effects = rspvep->side_effects;
    2183             :   }  /* if */
    2184             :   if (sequenced) {
    2185             :     /* The entries are sequenced, no need for diagnostics, just find the
    2186             :        end of the second list. */
    2187             :     last = NULL;
    2188             :     for (use = rspvep->uses; use != NULL; use = use->next) {
    2189             :       last = use;
    2190             :     }  /* for */
    2191             :   } else {
    2192             :     /* Issue diagnostics if uses and side-effects for the two lists
    2193             :        conflict. */
    2194             :     (void)check_for_unsequenced_uses(rspvep->side_effects, lspvep->uses);
    2195             :     last = check_for_unsequenced_uses(lspvep->side_effects, rspvep->uses);
    2196             :   }  /* if */
    2197             :   if (last != NULL) {
    2198             :     /* Merge the two lists of uses. */
    2199             :     last->next = lspvep->uses;
    2200             :     lspvep->uses = rspvep->uses;
    2201             :   }  /* if */
    2202             :   rspvep->uses = NULL;
    2203             :   rspvep->side_effects = NULL;
    2204             : }  /* merge_seq_pt_info_lists */
    2205             : 
    2206             : 
    2207             : static a_seq_pt_var_entry_ptr merge_lists_and_check_for_sequencing_issues(
    2208             :                                           a_seq_pt_var_entry_ptr lspvep,
    2209             :                                           a_seq_pt_var_entry_ptr rspvep,
    2210             :                                           a_boolean              sequenced,
    2211             :                                           a_boolean              is_assignment)
    2212             : /*
    2213             : Return a list of sequence point variable entries that contains entries from
    2214             : both lspvep and rspvep, issuing diagnostics when appropriate.  lspvep
    2215             : contains a list of sequence point variable entries for the left operand
    2216             : (or merged left-most operands) and rspvep contains a list of sequence point
    2217             : variable entries for the right (or next) operand.  sequenced is TRUE when the
    2218             : expression imposes a left-to-right sequencing on the operands (i.e., comma,
    2219             : question, logical and, and logical or operations).  is_assignment is TRUE when
    2220             : the side-effect in rspvep is the side-effect associated with an assignment
    2221             : expression.
    2222             : */
    2223             : {
    2224             :   a_seq_pt_var_entry_ptr copy, lprev = NULL;
    2225             :   a_seq_pt_var_entry_ptr result;
    2226             : 
    2227             :   if (lspvep == NULL) {
    2228             :     result = rspvep;
    2229             :   } else if (rspvep == NULL) {
    2230             :     result = lspvep;
    2231             :   } else {
    2232             :     /* Merge rspvep's elements into lspvep. */
    2233             :     result = lspvep;
    2234             :     while (lspvep != NULL && rspvep != NULL) {
    2235             :       /* The two lists are sorted using the variable's name as a key. */
    2236             :       int       ret = 0;
    2237             :       a_boolean found = FALSE;
    2238             :       if (lspvep->variable == rspvep->variable) {
    2239             :         /* This variable is common to both lists; merge the two lists of
    2240             :            side-effects into one list (lspvep), possibly issuing
    2241             :            diagnostics. */
    2242             :         merge_seq_pt_info_lists(lspvep, rspvep, sequenced, is_assignment);
    2243             :         lprev = lspvep;
    2244             :         lspvep = lspvep->next;
    2245             :         copy = rspvep;
    2246             :         rspvep = rspvep->next;
    2247             :         /* Now that the lists have been merged, free the unused list. */
    2248             :         free_seq_pt_entry_for_var(copy);
    2249             :         found = TRUE;
    2250             :       } else if ((ret = strcmp(lspvep->variable->source_corresp.name,
    2251             :                                rspvep->variable->source_corresp.name)) == 0) {
    2252             :         /* The entry on rspvep has the same name as an entry on lspvep, but
    2253             :            doesn't match the first such variable; see if there are any
    2254             :            other similarly named variables on the list that match. */
    2255             :         a_seq_pt_var_entry_ptr ptr = lspvep;
    2256             :         for (ptr = lspvep;
    2257             :              ptr != NULL;
    2258             :              ptr = ptr->next) {
    2259             :           if (ptr->variable == rspvep->variable) {
    2260             :             /* This variable is common to both lists; merge the two lists of
    2261             :                side-effects into one list (lspvep), possibly issuing
    2262             :                diagnostics. */
    2263             :             merge_seq_pt_info_lists(ptr, rspvep, sequenced, is_assignment);
    2264             :             copy = rspvep;
    2265             :             rspvep = rspvep->next;
    2266             :             /* Now that the lists have been merged, free the unused list. */
    2267             :             free_seq_pt_entry_for_var(copy);
    2268             :             found = TRUE;
    2269             :             /* Don't update lspvep (so it'll still point to the first
    2270             :                variable with this name). */
    2271             :             break;
    2272             :           }  /* if */
    2273             :           if (strcmp(ptr->variable->source_corresp.name,
    2274             :                      rspvep->variable->source_corresp.name) != 0) break;
    2275             :         }  /* for */
    2276             :       }  /* if */
    2277             :       if (!found) {
    2278             :         if (ret >= 0) {
    2279             :           /* Variable is on rspvep list but not lspvep; move it to lspvep. */
    2280             :           if (lprev == NULL) {
    2281             :             result = rspvep;
    2282             :           } else {
    2283             :             lprev->next = rspvep;
    2284             :           }  /* if */
    2285             :           lprev = rspvep;
    2286             :           copy = rspvep->next;
    2287             :           rspvep->next = lspvep;
    2288             :           rspvep = copy;
    2289             :         } else {
    2290             :           /* Variable is on lspvep list but not rspvep; leave it. */
    2291             :           lprev = lspvep;
    2292             :           lspvep = lspvep->next;
    2293             :         }  /* if */
    2294             :       }  /* if */
    2295             :     }  /* while */
    2296             :     if (rspvep != NULL) {
    2297             :       /* Everything on rspvep comes after everything on lspvep; move
    2298             :          the items from rspvep to lspvep. */
    2299             :       check_assertion(lprev != NULL);
    2300             :       lprev->next = rspvep;
    2301             :     }  /* if */
    2302             :   }  /* if */
    2303             :   return result;
    2304             : }  /* merge_lists_and_check_for_sequencing_issues */
    2305             : 
    2306             : #endif /* SEQUENCING_DIAGNOSTICS_ENABLED */
    2307             : 
    2308         448 : static a_boolean examine_expr_list_for_unordered_issues(
    2309             :                      an_expr_node_ptr                    expr_list,
    2310             :                      a_boolean                           sequenced,
    2311             :                      an_expr_or_stmt_traversal_block_ptr tblock)
    2312             : /*
    2313             : Examine the list of expressions headed by expr_list, and their
    2314             : subtrees, looking for unordered enk_temp_init initializations or
    2315             : unsequenced expressions with side-effects.  If any unordered enk_temp_inits
    2316             : are found, mark their dynamic initialization entries as unordered.  If
    2317             : tblock->set_unordered_on_dynamic_inits is TRUE, mark all enk_temp_init
    2318             : dynamic initializations as unordered (because of something detected
    2319             : higher up in the expression tree).  If sequenced is TRUE, the
    2320             : expressions on the list are sequenced left-to-right (e.g., because
    2321             : there is a sequence point after the first expression on the list).
    2322             : Creates a list (in tblock->seq_pt_var_list) of side-effects and uses
    2323             : of variables in the expression (when sequencing diagnostics are enabled).
    2324             : Return TRUE if there are any temp inits (unordered or not) in the
    2325             : expression list.
    2326             : */
    2327             : {
    2328         448 :   a_boolean        saved_result = tblock->result;
    2329         448 :   a_boolean        saved_set_unordered_on_dynamic_inits =
    2330             :                                         tblock->set_unordered_on_dynamic_inits;
    2331         448 :   a_boolean        any_temp_inits = FALSE;
    2332         448 :   an_expr_node_ptr expr, first_expr_with_temp_init = NULL;
    2333             : #if SEQUENCING_DIAGNOSTICS_ENABLED
    2334             :   a_seq_pt_var_entry_ptr
    2335             :                    expr_seq_pt_var_list = NULL;
    2336             :   a_seq_pt_var_entry_ptr
    2337             :                    save_seq_pt_var_list = tblock->seq_pt_var_list;
    2338             : #endif /* SEQUENCING_DIAGNOSTICS_ENABLED */
    2339             : 
    2340        1080 :   for (expr = expr_list; expr != NULL; expr = expr->next) {
    2341         632 :     a_boolean curr_expr_has_temp_init;
    2342             :     /* See whether this expression contains any temp inits. */
    2343         632 :     tblock->result = FALSE;
    2344             : #if SEQUENCING_DIAGNOSTICS_ENABLED
    2345             :     tblock->seq_pt_var_list = NULL;
    2346             : #endif /* SEQUENCING_DIAGNOSTICS_ENABLED */
    2347         632 :     traverse_expr(expr, tblock);
    2348         632 :     curr_expr_has_temp_init = tblock->result;
    2349         632 :     any_temp_inits |= curr_expr_has_temp_init;
    2350         632 :     if (curr_expr_has_temp_init &&
    2351             :         /* If we already know we're in an unordered region, we don't need
    2352             :            to do any further checking or processing.  We've already marked
    2353             :            any temp inits in the current expression as unordered. */
    2354         200 :         !tblock->set_unordered_on_dynamic_inits) {
    2355             :       /* There is at least one temp init in this expression. */
    2356             :       /* If there was a previous operand with a temp init, there's an
    2357             :          ordering problem. */
    2358         168 :       if (first_expr_with_temp_init != NULL) {
    2359          16 :         if (!sequenced) {
    2360             :           /* There was a previous expression with a temp init, and the
    2361             :              current expression has one as well, so there is an ordering
    2362             :              issue.  Go through the expressions up to this point and
    2363             :              set the unordered flag in them.  If there are more
    2364             :              expressions following the current one, they will be
    2365             :              processed as unordered as we continue through the list. */
    2366          16 :           an_expr_node_ptr texpr;
    2367          16 :           a_boolean        saved_relink_dynamic_inits =
    2368             :                                                   tblock->relink_dynamic_inits;
    2369          16 :           tblock->set_unordered_on_dynamic_inits = TRUE;
    2370          16 :           tblock->relink_dynamic_inits = FALSE;
    2371          32 :           for (texpr = first_expr_with_temp_init;; texpr = texpr->next) {
    2372          32 :             traverse_expr(texpr, tblock);
    2373          32 :             if (texpr == expr) break;
    2374             :           }  /* for */
    2375          16 :           tblock->relink_dynamic_inits = saved_relink_dynamic_inits;
    2376             :         }  /* if */
    2377             :       } else {
    2378             :         /* This is the first expression that has temp inits on the list. */
    2379             :         first_expr_with_temp_init = expr;
    2380             :       }  /* if */
    2381             :     }  /* if */
    2382             : #if SEQUENCING_DIAGNOSTICS_ENABLED
    2383             :     if (sequencing_diagnostics_enabled) {
    2384             :       /* Check for the presence of side-effects in unsequenced operations.
    2385             :          Most operations are unsequenced, that is, their operands can be
    2386             :          executed in any order.  This can cause undefined behavior in cases
    2387             :          where operands have side-effects (like increment, decrement,
    2388             :          assignment).  tblock->seq_pt_var_list has been set to a list of
    2389             :          side-effects and uses in the current operand.  Merge that list with
    2390             :          the side-effects and uses of any previous operands in this
    2391             :          expression. */
    2392             :       expr_seq_pt_var_list = merge_lists_and_check_for_sequencing_issues(
    2393             :                                                       expr_seq_pt_var_list,
    2394             :                                                       tblock->seq_pt_var_list,
    2395             :                                                       sequenced,
    2396             :                                                       /*is_assignment=*/FALSE);
    2397             :     }  /* if */
    2398             : #endif /* SEQUENCING_DIAGNOSTICS_ENABLED */
    2399             :   }  /* for */
    2400             : #if SEQUENCING_DIAGNOSTICS_ENABLED
    2401             :   if (save_seq_pt_var_list != NULL) {
    2402             :     /* This can occur when dynamic inits are intermixed with expressions,
    2403             :        e.g., "A *a = new (x++) A(x++);".  In this case, merge the two lists
    2404             :        (assuming they're not sequenced). */
    2405             :     expr_seq_pt_var_list = merge_lists_and_check_for_sequencing_issues(
    2406             :                                                       save_seq_pt_var_list,
    2407             :                                                       expr_seq_pt_var_list,
    2408             :                                                       /*sequenced=*/FALSE,
    2409             :                                                       /*is_assignment=*/FALSE);
    2410             :   }  /* if */
    2411             :   tblock->seq_pt_var_list = expr_seq_pt_var_list;
    2412             : #endif /* SEQUENCING_DIAGNOSTICS_ENABLED */
    2413         448 :   tblock->result = saved_result | any_temp_inits;
    2414         448 :   tblock->set_unordered_on_dynamic_inits= saved_set_unordered_on_dynamic_inits;
    2415         448 :   return any_temp_inits;
    2416             : }  /* examine_expr_list_for_unordered_issues */
    2417             : 
    2418             : 
    2419         144 : static void update_last_processed_dynamic_init(
    2420             :                                     a_dynamic_init_ptr                  dip,
    2421             :                                     an_expr_or_stmt_traversal_block_ptr tblock)
    2422             : /*
    2423             : The dynamic initialization entry pointed to by dip has been encountered
    2424             : while traversing an expression tree looking for unordered enk_temp_inits.
    2425             : Record it in tblock->last_relinked_dynamic_init as the latest entry
    2426             : encountered.  If dip is not the expected next entry, rearrange the
    2427             : destructions list.  This comes up when user-defined conversions are
    2428             : added to arguments of an overloaded function call.  When
    2429             : tblock->last_relinked_dynamic_init is NULL, assume the entry is in
    2430             : the right place; other entries from the expression will be moved
    2431             : following it as necessary when they come up (this is necessary
    2432             : in long lifetime temporaries mode, where there might be unrelated
    2433             : destructions preceding the first destruction from the expression).
    2434             : */
    2435             : {
    2436             :   /* Process only entries on a lifetime list, and only those on the
    2437             :      current lifetime list */

    2439         104 :       dip->lifetime != NULL && dip->lifetime == curr_object_lifetime) {
    2440          72 :     if (tblock->last_relinked_dynamic_init != NULL &&
    2441          48 :         dip->next_in_destruction_list != tblock->last_relinked_dynamic_init) {
    2442             :       /* The destruction is not at the right place on the list.  Move it. */
    2443           0 :       a_dynamic_init_ptr tdip = curr_object_lifetime->destructions;
    2444             :       /* Remove dip from the destructions list. */
    2445           0 :       if (tdip == dip) {
    2446             :         /* It's the first entry on the list. */
    2447           0 :         curr_object_lifetime->destructions = dip->next_in_destruction_list;
    2448             :       } else {
    2449             :         /* It's not the first entry on the list.  Find the entry preceding
    2450             :            it. */
    2451           0 :         for (;; tdip = tdip->next_in_destruction_list) {
    2452             : #if CHECKING
    2453           0 :           if (tdip == NULL) {
    2454             : #if DEBUG 
    2455           0 :             fprintf(f_debug, "Dynamic init not found:\n");
    2456           0 :             db_dynamic_initializer(dip, 2);
    2457           0 :             db_object_lifetime(curr_object_lifetime);
    2458             : #endif /* DEBUG */
    2459           0 :             unexpected_condition_str2("update_last_processed_dynamic_init:",
    2460             :                                       "dip not found");
    2461             :           }  /* if */
    2462             : #endif /* CHECKING */
    2463           0 :           if (tdip->next_in_destruction_list == dip) break;
    2464             :         }  /* for */
    2465           0 :         tdip->next_in_destruction_list = dip->next_in_destruction_list;
    2466             :       }  /* if */
    2467             :       /* Insert dip in the list, preceding
    2468             :          tblock->last_relinked_dynamic_init. */
    2469           0 :       tdip = curr_object_lifetime->destructions;

    2471             :         /* Insert at the beginning of the list. */
    2472           0 :         curr_object_lifetime->destructions = dip;
    2473             :       } else {
    2474             :         /* Find the point at which the insert is to be done. */
    2475           0 :         for (;; tdip = tdip->next_in_destruction_list) {
    2476             : #if CHECKING
    2477           0 :           if (tdip == NULL) {

    2479           0 :             fprintf(f_debug, "Dynamic init to insert:\n");

    2496          72 :     tblock->last_relinked_dynamic_init = dip;
    2497             :   }  /* if */

    2532         768 : static void examine_expr_for_unordered_issues(
    2533             :                                     an_expr_node_ptr                    expr,
    2534             :                                     an_expr_or_stmt_traversal_block_ptr tblock)
    2535             : /*
    2536             : Called from the expression traversal routines to process an expression
    2537             : as part of looking for unordered temp inits or unsequenced side-effects.
    2538             : */
    2539             : {
    2540         768 :   a_boolean                 sequenced;
    2541         768 :   an_expr_operator_kind     op;
    2542             : #if SEQUENCING_DIAGNOSTICS_ENABLED
    2543             :   a_seq_pt_var_entry_ptr    spvep;
    2544             :   a_seq_pt_info_entry_ptr   spiep;
    2545             : #endif /* SEQUENCING_DIAGNOSTICS_ENABLED */
    2546             : 
    2547         768 :   switch (expr->kind) {
    2548         408 :     case enk_operation:
    2549         408 :       op = expr->variant.operation.kind;
    2550         408 :       sequenced = FALSE;
    2551         408 :       switch (op) {
    2552           0 :         case eok_land:
    2553             :         case eok_lor:
    2554             :         case eok_vector_land:
    2555             :         case eok_vector_lor:
    2556             :         case eok_comma:
    2557             :         case eok_question:
    2558             :         case eok_vector_question:
    2559             :           /* Operators with a sequence point after the first never have
    2560             :              unordered operands.  The two-operand cases like a && b
    2561             :              obviously have no ordering issues, and in a ? b : c
    2562             :              b and c are not considered unordered with respect to
    2563             :              one another because only one of the two expressions will
    2564             :              be evaluated. */
    2565           0 :           sequenced = TRUE;
    2566           0 :           break;
    2567             :         default:
    2568             :           break;
    2569             :       }  /* switch */
    2570             :       /* The operands of an operation can be unordered, so handle them
    2571             :          specially. */
    2572         408 :       (void)examine_expr_list_for_unordered_issues(
    2573             :                                         expr->variant.operation.operands,
    2574             :                                         sequenced,
    2575             :                                         tblock);
    2576             : #if SEQUENCING_DIAGNOSTICS_ENABLED
    2577             :       if (sequencing_diagnostics_enabled &&
    2578             :           !tblock->set_unordered_on_dynamic_inits) {

    2580             :         a_boolean               is_assignment = FALSE;
    2581             :         an_expr_node_ptr        var_node;
    2582             :         switch (op) {

    2585             :                is invoked. */

    2588             :             break;
    2589             :           case eok_post_decr:
    2590             :           case eok_post_incr:
    2591             :             /* Most side-effects don't last through a value computation,
    2592             :                but post-increment and post-decrement are independent of
    2593             :                value computation. */
    2594             :             independent_of_value_computation = TRUE;
    2595             :             goto process_side_effect;
    2596             :           case eok_assign:
    2597             :           case eok_bassign:
    2598             :           case eok_add_assign:
    2599             :           case eok_subtract_assign:
    2600             :           case eok_multiply_assign:
    2601             :           case eok_divide_assign:
    2602             :           case eok_remainder_assign:
    2603             :           case eok_shiftl_assign:
    2604             :           case eok_shiftr_assign:
    2605             :           case eok_and_assign:
    2606             :           case eok_or_assign:
    2607             :           case eok_xor_assign:
    2608             :           case eok_padd_assign:
    2609             :           case eok_psubtract_assign:
    2610             :           case eok_pre_decr:    /* defined as += */
    2611             :           case eok_pre_incr:    /* defined as -= */
    2612             :             is_assignment = TRUE;
    2613             : process_side_effect:
    2614             :             var_node = expr->variant.operation.operands;
    2615             :             if (is_variable_node(var_node) &&
    2616             :                 has_name(node_variable(var_node))) {
    2617             :               /* This expression modifies the value of a variable; allocate
    2618             :                  a side-effect entry that captures this information and
    2619             :                  see if it conflicts with any existing side-effects or uses
    2620             :                  for the variable. */
    2621             :               /* Note that we're ignoring side-effects on operands that
    2622             :                  aren't variables (e.g., fields).  Further, only operations
    2623             :                  with side-effects that directly operate on variables are
    2624             :                  handled here, so for example, "(1, x) = x++" isn't flagged.
    2625             :                  An addressing path traversal of this node could be made,
    2626             :                  (though it would need to handle cases like
    2627             :                  "(0 ? y : x ) = x++" where there are multiple lvalues). */
    2628             :               check_assertion(var_node->is_lvalue);
    2629             :               spvep = alloc_seq_pt_var_entry(node_variable(var_node));
    2630             :               spiep = alloc_sequence_info_entry(var_node);
    2631             :               spiep->independent_of_value_computation =
    2632             :                                               independent_of_value_computation;
    2633             :               spiep->next = spvep->side_effects;
    2634             :               spvep->side_effects = spiep;
    2635             :               tblock->seq_pt_var_list =
    2636             :                                   merge_lists_and_check_for_sequencing_issues(
    2637             :                                                        tblock->seq_pt_var_list,
    2638             :                                                        spvep,
    2639             :                                                        is_assignment,
    2640             :                                                        is_assignment);
    2641             :             }  /* if */
    2642             :             break;
    2643             :           default:
    2644             :             break;
    2645             :         }  /* switch */
    2646             :       }  /* if */
    2647             : #endif /* SEQUENCING_DIAGNOSTICS_ENABLED */
    2648         408 :       tblock->suppress_subtree_walk = TRUE;
    2649         408 :       break;
    2650             : #if SEQUENCING_DIAGNOSTICS_ENABLED
    2651             :     case enk_variable:
    2652             :       if (sequencing_diagnostics_enabled &&
    2653             :           !tblock->set_unordered_on_dynamic_inits &&
    2654             :           !expr->is_lvalue &&
    2655             :           has_name(node_variable(expr))) {
    2656             :         /* Record a use of the variable in this expression. */
    2657             :         spvep = seq_pt_entry_for_var(&tblock->seq_pt_var_list,
    2658             :                                      node_variable(expr));
    2659             :         spiep = alloc_sequence_info_entry(expr);
    2660             :         spiep->next = spvep->uses;
    2661             :         spvep->uses = spiep;
    2662             :       }  /* if */
    2663             :       break;
    2664             : #endif /* SEQUENCING_DIAGNOSTICS_ENABLED */
    2665             :     case enk_new_delete:
    2666             :       /* There are no ordering issues for new and delete, though perhaps that
    2667             :          requires some explanation.  For delete, there's just the one operand,
    2668             :          so there's no ordering issue.  For new, generally the sequence is
    2669             :          (1) call of operator new to allocate, (2) set up freeing on exception,
    2670             :          (3) do initialization.  That's all done in order (you can't free
    2671             :          something until you've allocated it, and you can't initialize it
    2672             :          until you've allocated it and set up the freeing on exception during
    2673             :          the initialization).  In the case where the allocation is folded
    2674             :          into a constructor call or a runtime call (e.g., array new), there
    2675             :          will be no arguments for "new" and no freeing-on-destruction entry,
    2676             :          so the initialization is the only thing left and therefore it has
    2677             :          no ordering issues. */
    2678             :       break;
    2679             : #if GNU_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED
    2680           0 :     case enk_statement:
    2681             :       /* GNU statement expressions are much like function calls. */
    2682           0 :       tblock->suppress_subtree_walk = TRUE;
    2683           0 :       break;
    2684             : #endif /* GNU_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED */
    2685             :     default:
    2686             :       /* There are no ordering issues for other cases. */
    2687             :       break;
    2688             :   }  /* switch */
    2689         768 : }  /* examine_expr_for_unordered_issues */
    2690             : 
    2691             : #if SEQUENCING_DIAGNOSTICS_ENABLED
    2692             : 
    2693             : static void examine_constant_for_unordered_issues(
    2694             :                                     a_constant_ptr                      con,
    2695             :                                     an_expr_or_stmt_traversal_block_ptr tblock)
    2696             : /*
    2697             : Called from the expression traversal routines to process a constant
    2698             : as part of looking for unsequenced side-effects.
    2699             : */
    2700             : {
    2701             :   if (con->kind == (a_constant_repr_kind)ck_aggregate &&
    2702             :       !tblock->set_unordered_on_dynamic_inits) {
    2703             :     /* Each initializer in an aggregate is sequenced. */
    2704             :     a_seq_pt_var_entry_ptr save_seq_pt_var_list = tblock->seq_pt_var_list;
    2705             :     a_seq_pt_var_entry_ptr con_seq_pt_var_list = NULL;
    2706             :     for (con = con->variant.aggregate.first_constant;
    2707             :          con != NULL;
    2708             :          con = con->next) {
    2709             :       tblock->seq_pt_var_list = NULL;
    2710             :       traverse_constant(con, tblock);
    2711             :       con_seq_pt_var_list = merge_lists_and_check_for_sequencing_issues(
    2712             :                                                       con_seq_pt_var_list,
    2713             :                                                       tblock->seq_pt_var_list,
    2714             :                                                       /*sequenced=*/TRUE,
    2715             :                                                       /*is_assignment=*/FALSE);
    2716             :     }  /* for */
    2717             :     tblock->seq_pt_var_list = merge_lists_and_check_for_sequencing_issues(
    2718             :                                                       save_seq_pt_var_list,
    2719             :                                                       con_seq_pt_var_list,
    2720             :                                                       /*sequenced=*/FALSE,
    2721             :                                                       /*is_assignment=*/FALSE);
    2722             :     tblock->suppress_subtree_walk = TRUE;
    2723             :   }  /* if */
    2724             : }  /* examine_constant_for_unordered_issues */
    2725             :

    3208           8 : a_dynamic_init_ptr add_array_nonconstant_aggregate_init(
    3209             :                                          a_dynamic_init_ptr element_dip,
    3210             :                                          a_type_ptr         array_type,
    3211             :                                          a_type_ptr         elem_type,
    3212             :                                          a_routine_ptr      dtor_routine,
    3213             :                                          a_targ_size_t      number_of_elements)
    3214             : /*
    3215             : Change the indicated dynamic initialization into a dynamic initialization
    3216             : for each member of an array of classes.  array_type is the type of the array,
    3217             : and elem_type is the type of the array elements.  dtor_routine, if non-NULL,
    3218             : is the destructor associated with the element type.  number_of_elements is the
    3219             : number of elements in the array, or 0 if the number of elements is variable
    3220             : (and known only at runtime).  Multi-dimensional arrays are treated as
    3221             : single-dimensional arrays.  Return a pointer to the dynamic init entry for
    3222             : the entire array.
    3223             : */

    3231           0 :     record_dtor_in_dynamic_init(dtor_routine, element_dip,
    3232           0 :                                 curr_expr_is_potentially_evaluated());
    3233           0 :     record_partial_aggregate_cleanup_destruction(element_dip,
    3234           0 :                                                  curr_expr_is_evaluated());
    3235             :   }  /* if */
    3236             :   /* The IL structure is
    3237             :        new dynamic init (dik_nonconstant_aggregate) ->
    3238             :          constant (ck_aggregate) ->
    3239             :            constant (ck_init_repeat) ->
    3240             :              constant (ck_dynamic_init) ->
    3241             :                original dynamic init (dik_constructor)

    3244           8 :        alloc_expr_dynamic_init((a_dynamic_init_kind)dik_nonconstant_aggregate);

    3246             :                           number_of_elements);

    3250             : 
    3251           0 : void accumulate_array_size(a_type_ptr    array_type,
    3252             :                            a_targ_size_t *num_elements)

    3309             : #define is_reused_dynamic_init(expr)                                  \

    3313           0 : an_expr_node_ptr make_expr_reusable_copy(
    3314             :                                    an_expr_node_ptr expr,
    3315             :                                    a_boolean        vars_can_change,
    3316             :                                    a_boolean        *temp_init_used,
    3317             :                                    a_boolean        treat_as_potential_prvalue)
    3318             : /*
    3319             : Return a copy of the expression tree pointed to by expr, which is an
    3320             : prvalue or glvalue.  If it is a glvalue, it is one whose address can be
    3321             : taken (e.g., the caller has eliminated bit-field lvalues).  If the
    3322             : expression has side effects, or if its value is affected by the values
    3323             : of variables and vars_can_change is TRUE, the original expression will
    3324             : be changed so that its value (if it's a prvalue) or its address (if
    3325             : it's a glvalue) is stored in a temporary, and the copy will reference
    3326             : the temporary.  vars_can_change TRUE means arbitrary user code might
    3327             : be executed in the interval between the original use of the expression
    3328             : and the use of the copy, and such code might change the values of
    3329             : (user) variables.  *temp_init_used is returned TRUE if a temporary was
    3330             : used, including a reuse of an existing temporary.  When it is TRUE,
    3331             : the caller must take steps to ensure that expr is evaluated before the
    3332             : copy.  treat_as_potential_prvalue is TRUE in cases where the eventual
    3333             : value category of expr is not yet known (and can make a difference in
    3334             : determining whether or not the expression is invariant).
    3335             : treat_as_potential_prvalue should always be FALSE when called during
    3336             : lowering (as value category is known at that time).
    3337             : */
    3338             : {
    3339           0 :   an_expr_node_ptr   expr_copy, temp_init_expr;
    3340           0 :   a_dynamic_init_ptr dip;
    3341             : 
    3342             :   /* Only callable from within the expression routines.  See
    3343             :      make_reusable_copy_full for a similar routine usable in IL lowering. */
    3344           0 :   check_assertion(expr_stack != NULL);
    3345           0 :   *temp_init_used = FALSE;
    3346           0 :   if (is_reused_dynamic_init(expr)) {
    3347             :     /* The expression is already a reused value, probably generated by a
    3348             :        previous call of this routine.  Use the value again. */
    3349           0 :     dip = expr->variant.init.dynamic_init;
    3350           0 :     expr_copy = alloc_expr_node((an_expr_node_kind)enk_reuse_value);
    3351           0 :     expr_copy->variant.reused_value_init = dip;
    3352           0 :     expr_copy->type = expr->type;
    3353           0 :     *temp_init_used = TRUE;
    3354           0 :   } else if (is_operation_node(expr) &&
    3355           0 :              node_operator_is(expr, eok_indirect) &&
    3356           0 :              is_reused_dynamic_init(expr->variant.operation.operands)) {
    3357             :     /* The expression is an indirection on top of a reused value, probably
    3358             :        generated by a previous call of this routine with an lvalue expression.
    3359             :        Use the value again (with an indirection -- just like the source). */
    3360           0 :     dip = expr->variant.operation.operands->variant.init.dynamic_init;
    3361           0 :     expr_copy = alloc_expr_node((an_expr_node_kind)enk_reuse_value);
    3362           0 :     expr_copy->variant.reused_value_init = dip;
    3363           0 :     expr_copy->type = make_pointer_type(expr->type);
    3364           0 :     expr_copy = add_indirection_to_node(expr_copy);
    3365           0 :     *temp_init_used = TRUE;
    3366           0 :   } else if (is_invariant_expr(expr, vars_can_change,
    3367             :                                treat_as_potential_prvalue)) {
    3368             :     /* The expression has no side effects and will give the same value if
    3369             :        evaluated more than once. */
    3370             :     /* A straight copy will work. */
    3371             :     /* Note that this expression will not have temporaries or object lifetimes
    3372             :        in it since it has no side effects. */
    3373           0 :     an_expr_copy_options_set copy_options =
    3374           0 :                                     expr_stack->inside_conditional_expression ?
    3375           0 :                                              CE_INSIDE_CONDITIONAL_EXPRESSION :
    3376             :                                              CE_NO_OPTIONS;
    3377           0 :     expr_copy = copy_expr_tree(expr, copy_options);
    3378             :   } else {
    3379             :     /* Change the original expression to a dynamic initialization marked
    3380             :        with is_reused_value, and use an enk_reuse_value for the reuse.
    3381             :        For an lvalue case, the temporary is set to the address of the
    3382             :        lvalue, so the original expression "lvalue" becomes something like
    3383             :        "*(temp = &lvalue)". */
    3384           0 :     a_type_ptr       temp_type = expr->type;
    3385           0 :     an_expr_node_ptr expr_to_save = copy_node(expr);
    3386           0 :     a_boolean        lvalue_case = expr->is_lvalue;
    3387           0 :     if (lvalue_case) {
    3388           0 :       expr_to_save = add_address_of_to_node(expr_to_save);
    3389           0 :       temp_type = expr_to_save->type;
    3390             :     } else {
    3391             :       /* The operand shouldn't be a class in C++ (we don't want to copy it). */
    3392           0 :       check_assertion(C_mode() || !is_class_struct_union_type(temp_type));
    3393             :     }  /* if */
    3394           0 :     dip = alloc_expr_dynamic_init((a_dynamic_init_kind)dik_expression);

    3419       20582 : static a_boolean is_bit_field_extract_node(an_expr_node_ptr node)

    3421             : Return TRUE if the given expression node is a bit-field extraction.

    3425             : 
    3426       20582 :   if (is_operation_node(node) &&

    3428         853 :        node_operator_is((node), eok_points_to_field)) &&
