    8210             : 
    8211          18 : void cast_overloaded_function(a_type_ptr type_cast_to,
    8212             :                               an_operand *operand,
    8213             :                               a_boolean  is_cast,
    8214             :                               a_boolean  is_static_cast,
    8215             :                               a_boolean  skip_final_adjustment)
    8216             : /*
    8217             : Cast an operand for an overloaded function (*operand) to type_cast_to.
    8218             : If type_cast_to is a pointer, reference, or pointer-to-member type, the cast
    8219             : can serve to select one of the functions in the overload set.  See [over.over].
    8220             : If it doesn't, an error is issued.  If is_cast is TRUE, the disambiguation
    8221             : is being done via an explicit cast (a static_cast if is_static_cast is
    8222             : TRUE, otherwise an old-style or functional-notation cast); otherwise, it's
    8223             : implicit by context.  If skip_final_adjustment is TRUE, do not do the
    8224             : final type adjustment to get to type_cast_to; leave the operand as the
    8225             : raw type based on the function selected.
    8226             : */
    8227             : {
    8228          18 :   an_arg_match_level match_level;
    8229          18 :   a_symbol_ptr       function_symbol, overloaded_function_symbol;
    8230          18 :   a_std_conv_descr   std_conversion;
    8231          18 :   a_boolean          ambiguous, unknown_dependent_function;
    8232          18 :   a_boolean          reference_case = is_reference_type(type_cast_to);
    8233          18 :   a_boolean          reinterpret_semantics;
    8234             : 
    8235          18 :   overloaded_function_symbol = operand->symbol;
    8236          18 :   function_symbol =
    8237          36 :       find_addr_of_overloaded_function_match(overloaded_function_symbol,
    8238          18 :                                              (a_boolean)operand->
    8239             :                                                       is_template_id,
    8240             :                                              operand->template_arg_list,
    8241          18 :                                              is_a_function_designator(operand),
    8242             :                                              type_cast_to,
    8243             :                                              is_cast,
    8244             :                                              is_static_cast,
    8245             :                                              &match_level,
    8246             :                                              &std_conversion,
    8247             :                                              &reinterpret_semantics,
    8248             :                                              &unknown_dependent_function,
    8249             :                                              &ambiguous);
    8250          18 :   if (function_symbol != NULL) {
    8251             :     /* The cast selects one of the overloaded functions and is valid. */
    8252          18 :     a_boolean  access_error_reported;
    8253          18 :     an_operand orig_operand;
    8254          18 :     orig_operand = *operand;
    8255             :     /* Do whatever would have been done with the function if we had
    8256             :        known all along which function was intended.  Make an operand
    8257             :        for the specific function's address, a pointer-to-member for the
    8258             :        pointer to member case. */

    8316       17158 : static an_expr_node_ptr remove_cast_operations(an_expr_node_ptr  node)

    8407             : 
    8408      111524 : void cast_operand_full(a_type_ptr        new_type,
    8409             :                        an_operand        *operand,
    8410             :                        a_source_position *err_pos,
    8411             :                        a_boolean         check_cast_access,
    8412             :                        a_boolean         check_ambiguity,
    8413             :                        a_boolean         is_implicit_cast,
    8414             :                        a_boolean         is_reinterpret_cast,
    8415             :                        a_boolean         reinterpret_semantics)
    8416             : /*
    8417             : Cast the operand to the new type.  Check access on the cast if
    8418             : check_cast_access is TRUE.  Check ambiguity on the cast if check_ambiguity
    8419             : is TRUE.  If is_implicit_cast is TRUE, this is an implicit cast rather
    8420             : than an explicit one.  If there are any warnings detected on the
    8421             : type change, issue them only if is_implicit_cast is TRUE.  Issue
    8422             : those diagnostics at err_pos (if err_pos is NULL, use operand's position).
    8423             : If is_reinterpret_cast is TRUE, this cast appeared as reinterpret_cast in
    8424             : the source.  If reinterpret_semantics is TRUE, the operation has the same
    8425             : meaning as a reinterpret_cast, but it may come from another construct.
    8426             : The operand must be a prvalue or error operand.  The caller must have
    8427             : already determined that the conversion is allowed, except for casts to
    8428             : ambiguous or inaccessible base classes.  This routine does not handle
    8429             : user-defined conversions.
    8430             : */
    8431             : {
    8432      111524 :   a_boolean         did_not_fold;
    8433      111524 :   a_constant_ptr    local_con = local_constant();

    8692             : 
    8693       34674 : void cast_operand_special(a_type_ptr        new_type,
    8694             :                           an_operand        *operand,
    8695             :                           a_source_position *err_pos,
    8696             :                           a_boolean         check_cast_access,
    8697             :                           a_boolean         is_implicit_cast,
    8698             :                           a_boolean         is_reinterpret_cast,
    8699             :                           a_boolean         reinterpret_semantics)
    8700             : /*
    8701             : Another interface to cast_operand_full.  The "special" in this case
    8702             : is a Microsoft-bugs-mode weirdness that it's okay to cast or convert a
    8703             : pointer to a class to a pointer to an ambiguous base, as long as one of
    8704             : the ambiguous bases is a direct base class.  The code here checks for that
    8705             : case and produces a warning instead of an error for it.  This routine
    8706             : is called only in those contexts that allow this special laxity.
    8707             : */
    8708             : {
    8709       34674 :   a_boolean check_ambiguity = TRUE;
    8710             :

    8712             :     a_boolean        baseward_cast;

    8715             :         baseward_cast && bcp->ambiguous && bcp->direct) {

    8723             :     }  /* if */

    8750             : 
    8751             : 
    8752         719 : void base_class_cast_operand(an_operand       *operand,
    8753             :                              a_base_class_ptr bcp,
    8754             :                              a_type_ptr       qualifiers_model,
    8755             :                              a_boolean        check_cast_access,
    8756             :                              a_boolean        allow_ambiguity,
    8757             :                              a_boolean        is_implicit_cast,
    8758             :                              a_boolean        implicit_in_naming,
    8759             :                              a_boolean        is_object_pointer)
    8760             : /*
    8761             : Cast operand to its base class identified by bcp.  operand can be a
    8762             : prvalue pointer to class, or a class lvalue, xvalue, or prvalue.  In
    8763             : C++/CLI mode, it can also be a handle to a class.  The result will be
    8764             : of the same kind (pointer, lvalue, xvalue, prvalue, or handle).  If
    8765             : qualifiers_model is non-NULL, it is a class type whose cv-qualifiers
    8766             : are the model for the cv-qualifiers of the result (i.e., the result's
    8767             : type is the base class from bcp with the cv-qualifiers from
    8768             : qualifiers_model).  If qualifiers_model is NULL, the result will have
    8769             : the same cv-qualifiers as the original operand.  Do access control
    8770             : checking on the cast if check_cast_access is TRUE.  Allow an
    8771             : ambiguous reference if allow_ambiguity is TRUE.  The cast is
    8772             : implicit if is_implicit_cast is TRUE.  implicit_in_naming is TRUE for
    8773             : casts that are generated implicitly in referencing a member of a class
    8774             : (roughly, in getting from the name used in the source -- the
    8775             : projection symbol -- to the member actually used in the IL).
    8776             : is_object_pointer is TRUE if the pointer is asserted to be an object
    8777             : pointer (meaning it points at an object and is not a null pointer,
    8778             : though in fact the reason for this flag has to do with using 0 as a
    8779             : pointer in the usual version of the offsetof macro).  This routine is
    8780             : used only in C++ mode.
    8781             : */
    8782             : {
    8783         719 :   a_boolean        did_not_fold;
    8784         719 :   an_expr_node_ptr node;
    8785         719 :   a_constant_ptr   temp_con = local_constant();
    8786         719 :   an_operand       orig_operand;
    8787        1438 :   a_boolean        class_object_case =
    8788         719 :                                      !is_pointer_or_handle_type(operand->type);
    8789             : 
    8790             :   /* Save the original operand position, etc. */
    8791         719 :   orig_operand = *operand;
    8792         719 :   if (!base_class_cast_access_checking_should_be_done()) {
    8793         244 :     check_cast_access = FALSE;
    8794             :   }  /* if */
    8795         719 :   if (qualifiers_model == NULL) {
    8796         409 :     qualifiers_model = operand->type;
    8797         409 :     if (!class_object_case) {
    8798         242 :       qualifiers_model = type_pointed_to(qualifiers_model);
    8799             :     }  /* if */
    8800             :   }  /* if */
    8801             : #if MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED
    8802             :   if (cli_or_cx_enabled) {
    8803             :     a_type_ptr type = operand->type;

    8888        3405 : void adjust_glvalue_type(an_operand *operand,

    9032             : 
    9033         101 : void cast_operand_for_reference_cast(an_operand        *operand,
    9034             :                                      a_type_ptr        dest_type,
    9035             :                                      a_boolean         check_cast_access,
    9036             :                                      a_boolean         is_implicit_cast,
    9037             :                                      a_boolean         reinterpret_semantics)
    9038             : /*
    9039             : Cast *operand to a reference type given by dest_type.  That produces an
    9040             : lvalue of the type underlying dest_type as the result, or an xvalue if
    9041             : dest_type is an rvalue reference.  This cast does not make a new object;
    9042             : it merely adjusts the operand to access the same object with a new type.
    9043             : Check access on related-class casts if check_cast_access is TRUE.
    9044             : The cast is implicit if is_implicit_cast is TRUE.  Consider related-class
    9045             : adjustments only if reinterpret_semantics is FALSE (it is TRUE for
    9046             : reinterpret_cast).  The input operand is generally an lvalue, but it
    9047             : can be an rvalue when dest_type is an rvalue reference or when dest_type
    9048             : is an lvalue reference to const.
    9049             : */
    9050             : {

    9333             : 
    9334             : 
    9335        6506 : static a_boolean requires_bit_field_promotion(an_expr_node_ptr  node,
    9336             :                                               a_type_ptr        *p_type)
    9337             : /*
    9338             : A bit-field expression is a direct access to a bit field, or such an access
    9339             : under operations that maintain the bit-field nature of the access.  The exact
    9340             : meaning of this is unfortunately a little unclear in both the C and C++
    9341             : standards.  Still, if p->bf is a direct access to a bit field that is smaller
    9342             : than an int, the usual interpretation is that expressions like ++p->bf,
    9343             : (x, p->bf), and p->bf = 1 are still bit-field expressions and that if the
    9344             : accessed bit field is smaller than an int, the promoted type of the expression
    9345             : is int (even if the bit field itself has, e.g., unsigned int type).
    9346             : 
    9347             : This function returns TRUE if the given node is a bit-field expression (except
    9348             : in modes where bit-field expressions have no special treatment), and in that
    9349             : case it sets *p_type to the bit-field's promoted type.
    9350             : */
    9351             : {
    9352        6506 :   a_boolean    result = TRUE;
    9353        6506 :   a_field_ptr  fp = NULL;
    9354             : 
    9355        6506 :   if (microsoft_mode || C_dialect == C_dialect_pcc) {
    9356             :     /* pcc and MSVC don't treat bit fields in a special way. */
    9357           0 :     result = FALSE;
    9358           0 :     goto loop_done;
    9359        6506 :   } else if (!bit_field_promotion_applies_to_some_operations) {
    9360             :     /* Just check the case of a direct access to a bit field. */
    9361           0 :     if (is_bit_field_extract_node(node)) {
    9362           0 :       *p_type = type_after_bit_field_integral_promotion(node);
    9363             :     } else {
    9364             :       result = FALSE;
    9365             :     }  /* if */
    9366           0 :     goto loop_done;
    9367             :   }  /* if */
    9368        6514 :   for (;;) {
    9369        6514 :     if (!is_operation_node(node)) {
    9370        4116 :       result = FALSE;
    9371        4116 :       goto loop_done;
    9372             :     } else {
    9373        2398 :       switch (node->variant.operation.kind) {
    9374         210 :         case eok_dot_field:
    9375             :         case eok_points_to_field:
    9376         210 :           fp = node_field(node->variant.operation.operands->next);
    9377         210 :           if (fp->is_bit_field) {
    9378             :             /* The given expression was a bit-field expression.  Determine its
    9379             :                promoted type. */
    9380           0 :             *p_type = type_after_bit_field_integral_promotion(node);
    9381             :           } else {
    9382             :             result = FALSE;
    9383             :           }  /* if */
    9384         210 :           goto loop_done;
    9385           2 :         case eok_parens:
    9386             :         case eok_assign:
    9387             :         case eok_add_assign:
    9388             :         case eok_subtract_assign:
    9389             :         case eok_multiply_assign:
    9390             :         case eok_divide_assign:

    9398             :         case eok_psubtract_assign:
    9399             :           /* Operations that preserve the bit-field nature of their first
    9400             :              operand. */
    9401           2 :           node = node->variant.operation.operands;
    9402           2 :           break;
    9403           0 :         case eok_pre_incr:
    9404             :         case eok_pre_decr:
    9405           0 :           if (clang_mode) {
    9406             :             /* Clang doesn't promote the prefix increment/decrement
    9407             :                operations. */
    9408           0 :             result = FALSE;
    9409           0 :             goto loop_done;

    9419           0 :             result = FALSE;
    9420           0 :             goto loop_done;

    9422           6 :           node = node->variant.operation.operands;
    9423           6 :           break;

    9460      182416 : a_type_ptr operand_type_after_integral_promotion(an_operand *operand)

    9500       11722 : static void handle_nonstandard_array_rvalue(an_operand *operand)
    9501             : /*
    9502             : If operand is an array rvalue, convert it to a pointer to the first
    9503             : element of the array.  This is used for the nonstandard conversion
    9504             : in pre-C99 C.  A diagnostic is issued in strict mode.
    9505             : */
    9506             : {
    9507       11722 :   if (is_an_rvalue(operand) && is_array_type(operand->type)) {
    9508             :     /* For C++ and C99 mode, this should have been done earlier. */
    9509           0 :     check_assertion(C_mode() && !c99_mode);
    9510           0 :     if (strict_ansi_mode) {
    9511           0 :       expr_pos_diagnostic(strict_ansi_discretionary_severity,
    9512             :                           ec_bad_rvalue_array, &operand->position);
    9513             :     }  /* if */
    9514             :     /* Convert the array rvalue to a pointer to the first element. */
    9515           0 :     do_array_to_pointer_conversion(operand);    
    9516             :   }  /* if */
    9517       11722 : }  /* handle_nonstandard_array_rvalue */
    9518             : 
    9519             : 
    9520         665 : void arg_default_promote_operand(an_operand *argument_operand,
    9521             :                                  a_boolean  is_ellipsis)
    9522             : /*
    9523             : Do default argument promotions on an argument operand.  If the operand is
    9524             : a glvalue, it is converted to a prvalue before doing the promotions.
    9525             : is_ellipsis if the argument is being passed to an ellipsis.  If it's
    9526             : FALSE, we just have a case where we have no parameter information
    9527             : at all, which happens, for example, for an unprototyped function in
    9528             : C mode.
    9529             : */
    9530             : {
    9531         665 :   a_type_ptr  orig_arg_type, arg_type;
    9532             : 
    9533         665 :   if (microsoft_bugs && is_ellipsis &&
    9534             :       !curr_expr_is_evaluated() && is_an_lvalue(argument_operand) &&
    9535             :       is_incomplete_type(argument_operand->type) &&

    9538             :        as an argument to an ellipsis in a call in an unevaluated context.

    9540             :        so we don't call complete_type_is_needed here. */

    9543         665 :     do_operand_transformations(argument_operand, TOPT_NO_OPTIONS);

    9547             :   }  /* if */

    9549         665 :   arg_type = skip_typerefs(orig_arg_type);

    9785      133920 : static a_targ_size_t num_mantissa_bits(a_float_kind  fk)

    9819             : 
    9820       66960 : static a_float_kind promoted_float_kind(a_float_kind  fkind_1,
    9821             :                                         a_float_kind  fkind_2)
    9822             : /*
    9823             : fkind_1 and fkind_2 represent the precision of a floating-point type
    9824             : involved in a binary operation (or fk_last if the corresponding operand
    9825             : does not have a floating-point type).  Return the precision of the
    9826             : result (i.e., the precision to which both operands should be promoted).
    9827             : If both fkind_1 and fkind_2 are fk_last, then fk_last is returned.
    9828             : */
    9829             : {
    9830       66960 :   a_float_kind   result;
    9831       66960 :   a_targ_size_t  m_bits_1 = num_mantissa_bits(fkind_1),
    9832       66960 :                  m_bits_2 = num_mantissa_bits(fkind_2);
    9833             : 
    9834             :   /* The promoted kind is the one with the highest precision, except that
    9835             :      fk_float is replaced by fk_double in pcc mode.  If two different kinds
    9836             :      have equivalent precisions, return the "higher" kind (e.g., if fk_double
    9837             :      and fk_long_double are given, fk_long_double is returned even with
    9838             :      configurations that use the same representation for both). */
    9839       66960 :   if (m_bits_1 > m_bits_2 ||
    9840       66721 :       (m_bits_1 == m_bits_2 && fkind_1 > fkind_2)) {
    9841             :     result = fkind_1;
    9842             :   } else {
    9843       66721 :     result = fkind_2;
    9844             :   }  /* if */
    9845       66960 :   if (C_dialect == C_dialect_pcc && result == (a_float_kind)fk_float) {
    9846             :     result = (a_float_kind)fk_double;
    9847             :   }  /* if */
    9848       66960 :   return result;
    9849             : }  /* promoted_float_kind */
    9850             : 
    9851             : 
    9852       66960 : static a_type_ptr determine_arithmetic_conversions_full(
    9853             :                                                  an_operand *operand_1,
    9854             :                                                  a_type_ptr operand_1_type,
    9855             :                                                  an_operand *operand_2,
    9856             :                                                  a_type_ptr operand_2_type)
    9857             : /*
    9858             : Determine the "usual arithmetic conversions" on the operands to make them
    9859             : compatible, and return the type of the result.  Note that this routine assumes
    9860             : that the type is arithmetic, and does not actually change the operand types.
    9861             : See section 6.1.2.5 of the ISO C89 standard.  In C++, when wchar_t is a
    9862             : keyword, wchar_t is represented by one of the normal integral types and
    9863             : obeys the same conversion rules as its underlying type.  Likewise for bool,
    9864             : char16_t, and char32_t.  The operands can be lvalues or rvalues.  If operand_1
    9865             : is available only as a type, operand_1 == NULL and operand_1_type indicates the
    9866             : type.  Likewise for operand_2/operand_2_type.  Note that for some operations
    9867             : the operation type is different from the result type, and this routine does not
    9868             : determine a separate operation type.  Also see determine_vector_operation_type
    9869             : and determine_imaginary_operation_type, which handle some special cases in GNU
    9870             : and C99 modes (with operations having vector operands or imaginary operands):
    9871             : If those routines return TRUE, this routine should not be called.
    9872             : */
    9873             : {
    9874       66960 :   a_type_ptr      type_1 = (operand_1 != NULL) ? operand_1->type :
    9875             :                                                  operand_1_type;
    9876       66960 :   a_type_ptr      type_2 = (operand_2 != NULL) ? operand_2->type :
    9877             :                                                  operand_2_type;
    9878       66960 :   a_type_ptr      result_type;
    9879       66960 :   an_integer_kind ikind_1, ikind_2;
    9880             : 
    9881       66960 :   db_enter(4, "determine_arithmetic_conversions_full");
    9882             : 
    9883       66960 :   if (is_error_type(type_1) || is_error_type(type_2)) {
    9884           0 :     result_type = error_type();
    9885             :   } else {
    9886       66960 :     a_float_kind    fkind_1, fkind_2, result_fkind;
    9887             :     /* Get past possible typerefs. */
    9888       66960 :     type_1 = skip_typerefs(type_1);
    9889       66960 :     type_2 = skip_typerefs(type_2);
    9890             : 
    9891       66960 :     fkind_1 = is_floating_type(type_1) ? type_1->variant.float_kind :
    9892             :                                          (a_float_kind)fk_last;
    9893       66960 :     fkind_2 = is_floating_type(type_2) ? type_2->variant.float_kind :
    9894             :                                          (a_float_kind)fk_last;
    9895       66960 :     result_fkind = promoted_float_kind(fkind_1, fkind_2);
    9896       66960 :     if (result_fkind != (a_float_kind)fk_last) {
    9897             :       /* One of the operands had a (possibly complex) floating-point type. */
    9898             : #if C99_IL_EXTENSIONS_SUPPORTED
    9899        2112 :       if (is_nonreal_floating_type(type_1) ||
    9900        1056 :           is_nonreal_floating_type(type_2)) {
    9901             :         /* If the operands have the same "type domain" (real, complex, or
    9902             :            imaginary), the result has that same type domain.  Otherwise,
    9903             :            the result is complex.  Note that we don't get here if
    9904             :            both types are in the real domain; that's handled below. */
    9905           0 :         if (is_imaginary_type(type_1) && is_imaginary_type(type_2)) {
    9906           0 :           result_type = imaginary_type(result_fkind);
    9907             :         } else {
    9908           0 :           result_type = complex_type(result_fkind);
    9909             :         }  /* if */
    9910             :       } else
    9911             : #endif /* C99_IL_EXTENSIONS_SUPPORTED */
    9912             :       /* Do not insert code here. */
    9913             :       {
    9914        1056 :         result_type = float_type(result_fkind);
    9915             :       }  /* if */
    9916             : #if FIXED_POINT_ALLOWED
    9917       65904 :     } else if (fixed_point_enabled && (is_fixed_point_type(type_1) ||
    9918           0 :                                        is_fixed_point_type(type_2))) {
    9919             :       /* At least one of the operands has a fixed-point type, and the other
    9920             :          does not have a floating-point type.  The result will have a fixed-
    9921             :          point type, but no conversion is to be applied to the operands,
    9922             :          except to turn an unsigned operand into a signed operand. */
    9923           0 :       result_type = fixed_point_result_type(type_1, type_2);
    9924             : #endif /* FIXED_POINT_ALLOWED */
    9925             :     } else {

   10247             :   }  /* if */
   10248           0 : }  /* promote_operand_for_imaginary_operation */
   10249             : 
   10250             : 
   10251       25215 : a_boolean determine_imaginary_operation_type
   10252             :                                         (a_token_kind          op_token,
   10253             :                                          an_operand            *operand_1,
   10254             :                                          an_operand            *operand_2,
   10255             :                                          a_source_position     *err_pos,
   10256             :                                          a_type_ptr            *result_type,
   10257             :                                          an_expr_operator_kind *op)
   10258             : /*
   10259             : See whether the operation represented by op_token applied to operand_1
   10260             : and operand_2 is one of the special cases involving imaginary types
   10261             : that has an operation type different than the one determined by the
   10262             : usual arithmetic conversions.  If so, convert the operands to the
   10263             : proper operation type, set *result_type to the result type, set *op
   10264             : to the IL operator to be used, and return TRUE.  Otherwise, return FALSE,
   10265             : set *op to eok_last, and leave *result_type unchanged.  err_pos gives
   10266             : a source position for any errors.
   10267             : */
   10268             : {
   10269       25215 :   a_boolean     is_special = FALSE;
   10270       25215 :   a_boolean     is_imaginary_1, is_imaginary_2;
   10271       25215 :   a_type_ptr    type_1 = skip_typerefs(operand_1->type),
   10272       25215 :                 type_2 = skip_typerefs(operand_2->type);
   10273       25215 :   a_float_kind  fkind_1, fkind_2;
   10274       25215 :   a_float_kind  fkind_result = (a_float_kind)fk_float;
   10275       25215 :   a_boolean     is_compound_assignment = FALSE;
   10276             : 
   10277       25215 :   switch (op_token) {
   10278       23587 :     case tok_plus:
   10279             :     case tok_minus:
   10280             :     case tok_plus_assign:
   10281             :     case tok_minus_assign:
   10282       23587 :       is_imaginary_1 = is_imaginary_type(type_1);
   10283       23587 :       is_imaginary_2 = is_imaginary_type(type_2);
   10284       23587 :       if (!is_imaginary_1 && !is_imaginary_2) {
   10285             :         /* No imaginary types, so nothing special to check. */
   10286           0 :       } else if (is_imaginary_1 && is_imaginary_2) {
   10287             :         /* Imaginary + imaginary gives imaginary.  Likewise for -. */
   10288           0 :         is_special = TRUE;
   10289           0 :         fkind_1 = type_1->variant.float_kind;
   10290           0 :         fkind_2 = type_2->variant.float_kind;
   10291           0 :         fkind_result = promoted_float_kind(fkind_1, fkind_2);
   10292           0 :         *result_type = imaginary_type(fkind_result);
   10293             :         /* Determine the IL operator to use. */
   10294           0 :         switch (op_token) {
   10295           0 :           case tok_plus:
   10296           0 :             *op = (an_expr_operator_kind)eok_add;
   10297           0 :             break;
   10298           0 :           case tok_minus:
   10299           0 :             *op = (an_expr_operator_kind)eok_subtract;
   10300           0 :             break;
   10301           0 :           case tok_plus_assign:
   10302           0 :             *op = (an_expr_operator_kind)eok_add_assign;
   10303           0 :             is_compound_assignment = TRUE;
   10304           0 :             break;
   10305           0 :           case tok_minus_assign:
   10306           0 :             *op = (an_expr_operator_kind)eok_subtract_assign;
   10307           0 :             is_compound_assignment = TRUE;
   10308           0 :             break;
   10309             :           /* coverity[dead_error_begin] */
   10310           0 :           default:
   10311           0 :             unexpected_condition();
   10312             :         }  /* switch */
   10313           0 :       } else if ((op_token == tok_plus || op_token == tok_minus) &&
   10314           0 :                  ((is_imaginary_1 && is_real_floating_type(type_2)) ||
   10315           0 :                   (is_imaginary_2 && is_real_floating_type(type_1)))) {
   10316             :         /* Real + imaginary and similar combinations have special
   10317             :            operators.  We do not convert first to complex and then add
   10318             :            or subtract, because (a) it's less efficient, and (b) it
   10319             :            destroys negative zeroes.  See G.5.2 in the C99 standard. 
   10320             :            Note that += and -= are not handled specially. */
   10321           0 :         is_special = TRUE;
   10322           0 :         fkind_1 = type_1->variant.float_kind;
   10323           0 :         fkind_2 = type_2->variant.float_kind;
   10324           0 :         fkind_result = promoted_float_kind(fkind_1, fkind_2);

   10547      100574 : a_boolean determine_vector_operation_type(
   10548             :                                         a_token_kind           op_token,
   10549             :                                         an_operand             *operand_1,
   10550             :                                         an_operand             *operand_2,
   10551             :                                         a_source_position      *err_pos,
   10552             :                                         a_type_ptr             *operation_type,
   10553             :                                         an_expr_operator_kind  *op)
   10554             : /*
   10555             : Check whether the operation represented by op_token applied to operand_1 and
   10556             : operand_2 is a vector operation.  If so, set *operation_type to the type of the
   10557             : operation, *op to the IL operator kind (eok_...) representing this
   10558             : operation, and return TRUE.  If the operand types involve at least one vector
   10559             : type, but the operand types are not valid for a vector operation, issue an
   10560             : error at *err_pos and set *op to eok_error and *operation_type to an error type
   10561             : (TRUE is still returned in such cases).  Note that in some cases (notably
   10562             : relational and logical operations), the result of the operation (determined
   10563             : by the caller and not here) may be different than the type of the operation.
   10564             : */
   10565             : {
   10566      100574 :   a_type_ptr  op1_type = skip_typerefs(operand_1->type);
   10567      100574 :   a_type_ptr  op2_type = skip_typerefs(operand_2->type);

   10571             : 
   10572      100574 :   if (!op1_is_vec && !op2_is_vec) {

   10659             : 
   10660             : void adjust_constant_operand_info_for_microsoft_null_pointer_test(
   10661             :                                          an_operand       *operand,
   10662             :                                          a_boolean        *operand_is_constant,
   10663             :                                          a_constant       **operand_constant,
   10664             :                                          an_expr_node_ptr *con_expr)
   10665             : /*
   10666             : In Microsoft mode, expressions like (x, 0) are allowed as null pointer
   10667             : constants.  This routine examines *operand to see if it is such a thing,
   10668             : and sets *operand_is_constant and *operand_constant to the underlying
   10669             : null pointer constant.  Those are then presumably passed to a function
   10670             : like impl_conversion_possible, which would then conclude that it is
   10671             : possible to implicitly convert the *operand expression to a pointer type.
   10672             : This routine is called only in Microsoft mode.  If con_expr is non-NULL,
   10673             : *con_expr is set to point to the expression node that points to
   10674             : the null pointer constant returned in *operand_constant.
   10675             : */
   10676             : {
   10677             :   *operand_is_constant = FALSE;
   10678             :   if (is_expression_operand(operand)) {
   10679             :     an_expr_node_ptr expr = skip_parens(operand->variant.expression);
   10680             :     if (is_operation_node(expr) &&
   10681             :         expr->variant.operation.kind == (an_expr_operator_kind)eok_comma) {
   10682             :       /* The operand is a comma expression. */
   10683             :       expr = skip_parens(expr->variant.operation.operands->next);
   10684             :       if (is_constant_node(expr) &&
   10685             :           is_or_might_be_null_pointer_constant(node_constant(expr))) {
   10686             :         /* The operand is a comma node with a second operand that is a
   10687             :            null pointer constant, e.g., (x, 0). */
   10688             :         *operand_is_constant = TRUE;
   10689             :         *operand_constant = node_constant(expr);
   10690             :         if (con_expr != NULL) *con_expr = expr;
   10691             :       }  /* if */
   10692             :     }  /* if */
   10693             :   }  /* if */
   10694             : }  /* adjust_constant_operand_info_for_microsoft_null_pointer_test */
   10695             : 
   10696             : #endif /* MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED */
   10697             : 
   10698             : #if !MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED
   10699             : /*ARGSUSED*/  /* <-- operand is not used in that case. */
   10700             : #endif /* !MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED */
   10701       75419 : a_boolean operand_is_function(an_operand *operand)
   10702             : /*
   10703             : Return TRUE if the operand is an lvalue for or address of a specific
   10704             : function, but not an arbitrary pointer to function.  Likewise for
   10705             : a pointer-to-member for a specific function.  This matters only in
   10706             : C++/CLI, so return FALSE in other modes.
   10707             : */
   10708             : {
   10709       75419 :   a_boolean is_function = FALSE;
   10710             : 
   10711             : #if MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED

   10728             : 
   10729         730 : static a_boolean op_is_null_ptr_constant_for_comparison(an_operand  *opnd)
   10730             : /*
   10731             : Return TRUE if the given operand should be treated as a null pointer constant
   10732             : for a comparison operation.  Ordinarily, this produces the same result as
   10733             : op_is_null_pointer_constant, but in GNU and Microsoft modes some additional
   10734             : cases must be handled.
   10735             : */
   10736             : {
   10737         730 :   a_boolean  result = FALSE;
   10738             : 
   10739         730 :   if (op_is_null_pointer_constant(opnd)) {
   10740             :     result = !cppcli_enabled || is_plain_pointer_type(opnd->type);

   10755             : 
   10756             : 
   10757         365 : a_boolean check_compatibility_of_pointer_operands(

   10771             : type.  Return the operation type in *p_operation_type.  (The operands are not
   10772             : cast to the operation type; the caller must do that.)  operator_position gives

   11084             : 
   11085             : a_boolean check_compatibility_of_handle_operands(
   11086             :                                           an_operand        *operand_1,
   11087             :                                           an_operand        *operand_2,
   11088             :                                           a_source_position *operator_position,
   11089             :                                           a_type_ptr        *operation_type)
   11090             : /*
   11091             : operand_1 and operand_2 are the operands of a C++/CLI handle
   11092             : operation.  Check to see that the operands are compatible or can be
   11093             : made compatible.  One or the other of the operands, or both, must have
   11094             : a handle type.  Return the operation type in *operation_type.  (The
   11095             : operands are not cast to the operation type; the caller must do that.)
   11096             : operator_position gives the operator position (for errors).  Return
   11097             : FALSE if there is an error.
   11098             : */
   11099             : {
   11100             :   a_boolean        okay = FALSE;
   11101             :   a_type_ptr       operand_1_type = operand_1->type;

   11109             :        first operand. */

   11111             :                                operand_1_type,

   11116             :                                                 operand_1_type,
   11117             :                                                 (a_std_conv_descr *)NULL)) ||

   11120             :                                    (a_std_conv_descr *)NULL) ||
   11121             :         /* Conversion of nullptr to a value-constrained generic is not allowed
   11122             :            in general, but it is allowed in a handle comparison. */
   11123             :         (is_nullptr_type(operand_2_type) &&
   11124             :          !is_handle_type_not_value_generic(operand_1_type))) {
   11125             :       local_operation_type = operand_1_type;

   11137             :          cli_string_literal_conversion_possible(operand_1_type,

   11139             :                                                 (a_std_conv_descr *)NULL)) ||
   11140             :         boxing_conversion_possible(operand_1_type,
   11141             :                                    operand_2_type,
   11142             :                                    (a_std_conv_descr *)NULL) ||

   11144             :            in general, but it is allowed in a handle comparison. */

   11146             :          !is_handle_type_not_value_generic(operand_2_type))) {
   11147             :       local_operation_type = operand_2_type;
   11148             :       okay = TRUE;
   11149             :     }  /* if */
   11150             :   }  /* if */
   11151             :   if (okay &&
   11152             :       ((operand_1_is_handle &&

   11192           0 : a_boolean check_compatibility_of_nullptr_operands(

   11196             :                                           a_type_ptr        *operation_type)

   11411           0 : void check_mixed_integer_fixed_point_arithmetic(

   11415             : /*

   11465           0 : static void adjust_fixed_point_binary_operands(
   11466             :                                             an_operand             *operand_1,
   11467             :                                             an_operand             *operand_2,
   11468             :                                             an_expr_operator_kind  op)
   11469             : /*
   11470             : A binary operation (op) is to be applied to the two given operands, at least
   11471             : one of which has a fixed-point type.  Apply any required conversions to the
   11472             : operands.  The only conversion this can be is from an unsigned fixed-point
   11473             : type to the corresponding signed fixed-point type (when operating on two
   11474             : fixed-point operands of differing signedness).  Issue a warning if the
   11475             : operand types are unlikely to be intended for the given operation (e.g.,
   11476             : adding an integer to fixed-point type.)
   11477             : */
   11478             : {
   11479           0 :   a_type_ptr  tp1 = skip_typerefs(operand_1->type),
   11480           0 :               tp2 = skip_typerefs(operand_2->type);
   11481             : 
   11482           0 :   if (tp1->kind == (a_type_kind)tk_fixed_point &&
   11483           0 :       tp2->kind == (a_type_kind)tk_fixed_point) {
   11484           0 :     if (tp1->variant.fixed_point.is_unsigned !=
   11485             :                                        tp2->variant.fixed_point.is_unsigned) {
   11486             :       /* One of the two operands needs to be converted to a signed type. */
   11487           0 :       an_operand  *operand_to_adjust;

   11490           0 :         if (is_compound_assignment_operator(op)) {
   11491             :           /* The first operand of a compound assignment operation cannot be
   11492             :              explicitly adjusted (the adjustment is implicit in that case). */
   11493             :           operand_to_adjust = NULL;
   11494             :         } else {
   11495             :           operand_to_adjust = operand_1;
   11496             :           type = tp1;
   11497             :         }  /* if */
   11498             :       } else {
   11499             :         operand_to_adjust = operand_2;
   11500             :         type = tp2;
   11501             :       }  /* if */
   11502           0 :       if (operand_to_adjust != NULL) {
   11503           0 :         type = fixed_point_type(

   11505           0 :                                 type->variant.fixed_point.precision,
   11506             :                                 /*is_unsigned=*/FALSE,
   11507             :                                 (a_boolean)type

   11521             : 
   11522             : 
   11523             : /*
   11524             : Macro to issue a warning for usual arithmetic conversions that end up
   11525             : converting a fixed-point value to a floating-point type.  (Such a warning
   11526             : is suggested by TR 18037.)
   11527             : */
   11528             : #define warn_on_fixed_point_to_floating_point_conversion(operand, type)      \
   11529             :   if (fixed_point_enabled && is_fixed_point_type((operand)->type) &&         \
   11530             :       is_floating_type((type))) {                                            \
   11531             :     expr_pos_warning(ec_implicit_fixed_point_to_floating_point_conversion,   \
   11532             :                      &(operand)->position);                                  \
   11533             :   }  /* if */
   11534             : 
   11535             : #endif /* FIXED_POINT_ALLOWED */
   11536             : 
   11537             : #if !FIXED_POINT_ALLOWED
   11538             : /*ARGSUSED*/  /* <-- op not used in that case. */
   11539             : #endif /* !FIXED_POINT_ALLOWED */
   11540       67090 : void change_binary_operand_types(a_type_ptr             type,
   11541             :                                  an_operand             *operand_1,
   11542             :                                  an_operand             *operand_2,
   11543             :                                  an_expr_operator_kind  op)
   11544             : /*
   11545             : The given operation will be applied to the given operands.  If type is not a
   11546             : fixed-point type, cast the two operands to the new type if necessary.
   11547             : Otherwise (if type is a fixed-point type), ensure the operand types have the
   11548             : appropriate signedness (according to the rules prescribed by ISO TR 18037
   11549             : for fixed-point arithmetic).  This is used for the operands of an operation,
   11550             : with the type probably determined by determine_arithmetic_conversions.
   11551             : Either operand pointer may be NULL.  Warnings may be issued if fixed-point
   11552             : operands are unlikely to have a useful effect (e.g., when adding an integer
   11553             : to a fixed-point operand).
   11554             : */
   11555             : {
   11556             : #if FIXED_POINT_ALLOWED
   11557       67090 :   if (fixed_point_enabled && is_fixed_point_type(type) &&
   11558             :       op != (an_expr_operator_kind)eok_question) {
   11559             :     /* Fixed-point arithmetic does not promote the operands to a

   11562             :        handling of converting the operands to the result type. */

   11588         258 : static a_boolean is_nonreal_member_constant(a_constant_ptr con,

   11618         234 : void change_template_param_constant_operand_to_lvalue(an_operand *operand)
   11619             : /*

   11651             : 
   11652         171 : static an_expr_node_ptr conv_nonreal_member_constant_expr_to_lvalue(
   11653             :                                                  an_expr_node_ptr expr,
   11654             :                                                  a_boolean        *is_function)
   11655             : /*
   11656             : Helper routine for change_nonreal_member_constant_operand_to_lvalue:
   11657             : Look for a prvalue for a nonreal member within the expression expr.
   11658             : If one is found, rewrite it as an lvalue and rewrite every node above it
   11659             : as an lvalue, and return a pointer to the rewritten nonreal member node.
   11660             : Also return *is_function set to TRUE if the node is for a nonreal
   11661             : member function.  If no nonreal member is found, return NULL.
   11662             : */
   11663             : {
   11664         171 :   an_expr_node_ptr rewritten_expr = NULL;
   11665             : 
   11666         171 :   *is_function = FALSE;

   11668         171 :     if (is_constant_node(expr)) {
   11669           0 :       a_constant_ptr con = node_constant(expr);

   11671             :         /* Add an eok_lvalue node to make the nonreal member an lvalue. */

   11673           0 :         check_assertion(!new_expr->is_lvalue);

   11676           0 :                                         expr->variant.constant.name_reference;

   11678             :                                              new_expr->type, new_expr);
   11679           0 :         overwrite_node(expr, new_expr);
   11680           0 :         rewritten_expr = expr;

   11683         171 :                (node_operator_is(expr, eok_dot_static) ||
   11684             :                 node_operator_is(expr, eok_points_to_static))) {

   11686           0 :       an_expr_node_ptr op1 = expr->variant.operation.operands;

   11688             :                                                                   is_function);

   11708             : 
   11709         886 : void change_nonreal_member_constant_operand_to_lvalue(an_operand *operand)
   11710             : /*
   11711             : If the indicated operand is a prvalue indicating the value of a
   11712             : member of a nonreal class, change it to an lvalue that refers to
   11713             : the member.  Likewise for a prvalue for the address of an unknown function.
   11714             : The idea here is that we have a reference to a member which has unknown
   11715             : value category, and we have found out that it needs to be an lvalue, so
   11716             : we rewrite it as an lvalue.
   11717             : */
   11718             : {
   11719         886 :   an_expr_node_ptr expr = NULL;
   11720         886 :   a_boolean        is_function = FALSE;
   11721             : 
   11722         886 :   if (is_a_prvalue(operand)) {
   11723         195 :     if (is_constant_operand(operand)) {
   11724          24 :       a_constant_ptr con = &operand->variant.constant;
   11725          24 :       if (is_nonreal_member_constant(con, &is_function)) {
   11726          24 :         change_template_param_constant_operand_to_lvalue(operand);
   11727           0 :       } else if (con->kind == (a_constant_repr_kind)ck_template_param &&
   11728           0 :                  con->variant.template_param.kind ==
   11729             :                              (a_template_param_constant_kind)tpck_expression) {
   11730           0 :         expr = expr_node_from_tpck_expression(con);
   11731             :       }  /* if */
   11732         171 :     } else if (is_expression_operand(operand)) {
   11733         171 :       expr = operand->variant.expression;
   11734             :     }  /* if */
   11735             :   }  /* if */
   11736         195 :   if (expr != NULL) {
   11737             :     /* Attempt to rewrite the underlying expression "expr". */
   11738         171 :     an_expr_node_ptr rewritten_expr;
   11739         171 :     if (!expr->is_lvalue) {
   11740         171 :       rewritten_expr =
   11741         171 :                conv_nonreal_member_constant_expr_to_lvalue(expr, &is_function);
   11742             :     } else {
   11743             :       /* In some modes (Microsoft mode in particular), nonreal prvalue operands
   11744             :          may have an underlying lvalue expression.  For example:
   11745             :              template<typename T> struct A {};
   11746             :              template<typename T, A<typename T::N> const &R> struct B {
   11747             :                typedef B<T, R> thistype;
   11748             :              };
   11749             :              template<class T, A<typename T::N> const &R> struct D: B<T, R> {};
   11750             :          Here, during a nonreal instantiation of B<T, R>, the bound R in the
   11751             :          typedef has an underlying lvalue expression (eok_ref_indirect). */
   11752             :       rewritten_expr = expr;
   11753             :     }  /* if */
   11754         171 :     if (rewritten_expr != NULL) {
   11755             :       /* A nonreal member constant was found and rewritten. */
   11756           0 :       an_operand orig_operand;
   11757           0 :       orig_operand = *operand;
   11758           0 :       check_assertion(expr->is_lvalue && rewritten_expr->is_lvalue);
   11759           0 :       make_glvalue_expression_operand(expr, operand);
   11760           0 :       if (is_function) {
   11761           0 :         operand->state = (an_operand_state)os_function_designator;
   11762             :       }  /* if */
   11763           0 :       restore_operand_details(operand, &orig_operand);
   11764             :     }  /* if */
   11765             :   }  /* if */
   11766         886 : }  /* change_nonreal_member_constant_operand_to_lvalue */
   11767             : 
   11768             : 
   11769           0 : static void revert_class_prvalue_to_lvalue_if_possible(an_operand *operand)
   11770             : /*
   11771             : If the given operand is a class prvalue, try to change it back to
   11772             : an lvalue.  This is used in GNU and Microsoft modes, which believe
   11773             : that some class prvalues can be used as lvalues (e.g., a function call
   11774             : returning a class by value).
   11775             : */
   11776             : {
   11777           0 :   if (!C_mode() &&
   11778           0 :       is_a_prvalue(operand) &&
   11779           0 :       is_class_struct_union_type(operand->type) &&
   11780           0 :       is_expression_operand(operand)) {
   11781           0 :     an_expr_node_ptr expr = skip_parens(operand->variant.expression);
   11782           0 :     a_boolean        revertible = FALSE;
   11783           0 :     check_assertion(!expr->is_lvalue);
   11784           0 :     if (expr->kind == (an_expr_node_kind)enk_temp_init) {
   11785           0 :       a_dynamic_init_ptr dip = expr->variant.init.dynamic_init;
   11786           0 :       if (dip->kind == (a_dynamic_init_kind)dik_constructor) {
   11787             :         /* A "constructor call" can be turned back into an lvalue. */
   11788             :         revertible = TRUE;
   11789           0 :       } else if (dip->kind == (a_dynamic_init_kind)dik_expression) {
   11790             :         /* This is probably a base-class cast on top of another
   11791             :            temp-init. */
   11792             :         revertible = TRUE;
   11793           0 :       } else if (dip->kind == (a_dynamic_init_kind)dik_class_result_via_ctor) {
   11794             :         /* A function call (or statement expression) returning a class rvalue
   11795             :            can be turned back into an lvalue. */
   11796             :         revertible = TRUE;
   11797           0 :       } else if (dip->kind == (a_dynamic_init_kind)dik_zero) {
   11798             :         /* A trivial constructor call with value-initialization. */
   11799             :         revertible = TRUE;
   11800             :       }  /* if */
   11801           0 :     } else if (is_operation_node(expr)) {
   11802           0 :       if (is_call_node(expr)) {
   11803             :         /* A function call that returns a class can be changed back
   11804             :            into an lvalue. */
   11805             :         revertible = TRUE;
   11806             :       } else if (microsoft_mode && node_operator_is(expr, eok_question)) {
   11807             :         /* A class rvalue "?" can be turned into an lvalue in Microsoft
   11808             :            mode. */

   11812             :                microsoft_mode) {
   11813             :       /* A lambda value can be turned into an lvalue. */
   11814             :       revertible = TRUE;
   11815             :     }  /* if */
   11816             :     if (revertible) {
   11817             :       /* Change the rvalue back into an lvalue. */
   11818           0 :       conv_class_prvalue_operand_to_lvalue(operand);
   11819             :     }  /* if */
   11820             :   }  /* if */
   11821           0 : }  /* revert_class_prvalue_to_lvalue_if_possible */
   11822             : 
   11823             : 
   11824        5349 : void revert_gcc_rvalue_to_lvalue_if_possible_full(
   11825             :                                                an_operand *operand,
   11826             :                                                a_boolean  ignore_casts,
   11827             :                                                a_boolean  drop_same_size_casts)
   11828             : /*
   11829             : Called only in gcc or g++ mode in a context where an lvalue is required.
   11830             : If operand is a prvalue that can be turned back into an lvalue, do
   11831             : the transformation.  If ignore_casts is TRUE, casts on an lvalue do
   11832             : not interfere with turning it back into an lvalue (this is true,
   11833             : for example, in something like "(short)i = 0").  If drop_same_size_casts
   11834             : is TRUE, integral casts to same-sized types are dropped even
   11835             : when gnu_version would ordinarily indicate they should not be.
   11836             : */
   11837             : {
   11838        5349 :   an_operand orig_operand;
   11839             : 
   11840        5349 :   check_assertion(gnu_mode);
   11841        5349 :   if (is_a_prvalue(operand) && !is_void_type(operand->type)) {
   11842           0 :     if (is_expression_operand(operand)) {
   11843           0 :       a_boolean             do_recovery = FALSE;
   11844           0 :       a_boolean             casts_removed = FALSE;
   11845           0 :       a_type_ptr            type_cast_to = NULL, type_before_cast = NULL;
   11846           0 :       an_expr_node_ptr      expr = skip_parens(operand->variant.expression);
   11847           0 :       an_expr_operator_kind op = (an_expr_operator_kind)eok_error;
   11848           0 :       a_boolean             same_size_cast_case = FALSE;
   11849           0 :       if (gpp_mode && gnu_version < 40000 &&
   11850           0 :           is_operation_node(expr) &&
   11851           0 :           expr->variant.operation.kind == (an_expr_operator_kind)eok_cast) {
   11852           0 :         type_cast_to = expr->type;
   11853           0 :         type_before_cast = expr->variant.operation.operands->type;
   11854           0 :         if (identical_types(type_cast_to, type_before_cast)) {
   11855             :           /* g++ ignores a cast to the same type. */
   11856           0 :           expr = skip_parens(expr->variant.operation.operands);
   11857             :         }  /* if */
   11858             :       }  /* if */
   11859           0 :       if (drop_same_size_casts &&
   11860           0 :           is_operation_node(expr) &&
   11861           0 :           expr->variant.operation.kind == (an_expr_operator_kind)eok_cast) {
   11862             :         /* See whether the top operation is a same-sized cast that should
   11863             :            be dropped. */
   11864           0 :         type_cast_to = expr->type;
   11865           0 :         type_before_cast = expr->variant.operation.operands->type;

   11869           0 :                                          f_skip_typerefs(type_cast_to)->size) {

   11877           0 :           (op == (an_expr_operator_kind)eok_cast ||
   11878           0 :            (gcc_mode &&
   11879           0 :             (op == (an_expr_operator_kind)eok_question ||

   11885             :         /* See whether we can find an underlying lvalue. */
   11886           0 :         expr = conv_prvalue_expr_to_lvalue(expr, &do_recovery,

   11891           0 :         if (ignore_casts && do_recovery && cast_on_top_originally &&
   11892           0 :             expr != orig_expr) {
   11893             :           /* One or more casts was removed. */
   11894           0 :           casts_removed = TRUE;
   11895           0 :           type_cast_to = orig_expr->type;
   11896           0 :           type_before_cast = expr->type;
   11897             :         }  /* if */
   11898           0 :       } else if (!C_mode() &&
   11899           0 :                  is_operation_node(expr) &&
   11900           0 :                  op == (an_expr_operator_kind)eok_dot_field &&
   11901           0 :                  !expr->variant.operation.operands->is_lvalue) {
   11902             :         /* A field selection out of an rvalue in C++ can be converted to an
   11903             :            lvalue selection. */
   11904           0 :         an_expr_node_ptr texpr = expr->variant.operation.operands;
   11905           0 :         an_expr_node_ptr texpr2 = texpr->next;
   11906           0 :         a_field_ptr      field = node_field(texpr2);
   11907           0 :         an_operand       class_operand;

   11909             :         /* Turn the first operand, the class object, into an lvalue. */
   11910           0 :         make_expression_operand(texpr, &class_operand);

   11913           0 :           orig_operand = *operand;

   11915           0 :           texpr = class_operand.variant.expression;

   11918           0 :           make_glvalue_expression_operand(texpr, operand);

   11921             :           /* We failed to make an lvalue.  Keep the original operation
   11922             :              and  relink the operands. */
   11923           0 :           texpr->next = texpr2;
   11924             :         }  /* if */
   11925           0 :       } else if (!C_mode() &&
   11926           0 :                  is_class_struct_union_type(operand->type)) {
   11927             :         /* A function call returning a class value can be treated as
   11928             :            an lvalue. */
   11929           0 :         revert_class_prvalue_to_lvalue_if_possible(operand);
   11930           0 :       } else if (gcc_mode && gnu_version < 40000 && is_variable_node(expr)) {
   11931             :         /* In some unusual cases, like optimizing "(1 ? a : a)" to
   11932             :            simply "a", we may have to turn a variable back into an
   11933             :            lvalue for the variable. */
   11934           0 :         do_recovery = TRUE;
   11935             :       }  /* if */
   11936           0 :       if (do_recovery) {
   11937             :         /* Yes, an lvalue can be recovered. */
   11938           0 :         a_type_ptr cast_type = NULL;
   11939           0 :         orig_operand = *operand;
   11940           0 :         if (casts_removed) {
   11941           0 :           if (gcc_mode &&
   11942           0 :               still_an_lvalue(type_before_cast, type_cast_to)) {
   11943             :             /* gcc treats certain "near-enough" casts as lvalue casts
   11944             :                if it needs an lvalue. */
   11945           0 :             cast_type = type_cast_to;
   11946             :           }  /* if */

   12682             : 
   12683       61612 : static a_boolean valid_node_if_subscript(an_expr_node_ptr node,
   12684             :                                          a_boolean        *just_past_end,
   12685             :                                          an_error_code    *err_code)
   12686             : /*
   12687             : Check the given node to see if it represents a subscript operation with a
   12688             : constant subscript.  If so, check the subscript and return FALSE if it's not
   12689             : valid.  Return *just_past_end TRUE if the subscript is just past the end
   12690             : of the array (which is legal when the address is used, but not when the
   12691             : value is used).  The node can be an lvalue or an rvalue.  Pointer additions
   12692             : and subtractions are also checked (e.g., a + 5, where 5 is beyond the end
   12693             : of the array a).  This routine checks these operations when the
   12694             : pointer operand is not constant; when it is, the folding routines
   12695             : (e.g., do_padd) do the check.  It is important that the check be done
   12696             : only once, so that a warning is issued only once.  Therefore, it is done
   12697             : immediately when the operator is scanned, either in the constant
   12698             : folding or here.  Subscript operations are always lvalues initially,
   12699             : and therefore not constant, and are therefore always checked here.
   12700             : When a constant addressing expression is folded to a constant later,
   12701             : no warning is generated for an invalid subscript or pointer operation,
   12702             : on the assumption that the warning was already generated when the
   12703             : operator was scanned.  *err_code is set to the error code for an
   12704             : appropriate warning (the pointer +/- cases use a different message than
   12705             : the subscript case).
   12706             : */
   12707             : {
   12708       61612 :   a_boolean        valid = TRUE;
   12709       61612 :   an_expr_node_ptr ptr_node, sub_node;
   12710       61612 :   a_type_ptr       ptr_type, underlying_type, array_type, element_type;
   12711       61612 :   a_type_ptr       ptr_element_type;
   12712       61612 :   a_constant_ptr   sub_con;
   12713       61612 :   a_targ_size_t    num_elements;
   12714       61612 :   int              cmp;
   12715       61612 :   a_boolean        prev_subsc_just_past_end = FALSE;
   12716             : 
   12717       61612 :   *just_past_end = FALSE;
   12718       61612 :   *err_code = ec_no_error;
   12719       61612 :   node = skip_parens(node);
   12720       61612 :   if (is_operation_node(node) &&
   12721       31231 :       node_operator_is(node, eok_indirect)) {
   12722         979 :     ptr_node = skip_parens(node->variant.operation.operands);

   12724         708 :       if (node_operator_is(ptr_node, eok_array_to_pointer)) {
   12725             :         /* Indirection over an array-decay is effectively a [0] subscript at
   12726             :            the end, i.e., *a[3] is the same as a[3][0] if a is a
   12727             :            two-dimensional array.  Since the final effective subscript is [0],
   12728             :            do the subscript analysis on the previous subscript, and its
   12729             :            validity and just-past-end flag will be correct for this level
   12730             :            as well. */
   12731           0 :         node = skip_parens(ptr_node->variant.operation.operands);

   12820           0 :                   a_boolean err;
   12821           0 :                   if (!int_constant_is_signed(sub_con)) goto invalid_subscript;
   12822           0 :                   *local_con = *sub_con;
   12823           0 :                   eff_sub_con = local_con;
   12824           0 :                   negate_integer_value(&local_con->variant.integer_value,
   12825             :                                        &err);
   12826           0 :                   if (err) goto invalid_subscript;
   12827             :                 }  /* if */
   12828         175 :                 if (sign_of_integer_constant(eff_sub_con) < 0) {
   12829             :                   /* Negative subscript (positive for pointer "-"). */
   12830           0 : invalid_subscript:
   12831             :                   valid = FALSE;
   12832         175 :                 } else if (prev_subsc_just_past_end) {
   12833             :                   /* A previous subscript was just past the end. */
   12834           0 :                   if (sign_of_integer_constant(eff_sub_con) == 0) {
   12835             :                     /* This one is zero, so we're still just at the end. */
   12836           0 :                     *just_past_end = TRUE;
   12837             :                   } else {
   12838             :                     /* This one is positive, so we're off the end. */
   12839             :                     valid = FALSE;
   12840             :                   }  /* if */
   12841         175 :                 } else if (vla_enabled && is_vla_type(underlying_type)) {

   12843             :                      subscripts. */
   12844             : #if UPC_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED
   12845         175 :                 } else if (array_type->variant.array.is_threads_dimension) {

   12854             :                                      variant.array.variant.number_of_elements;

   12857             :                      is cheating. */

   12859         164 :                     cmp = cmpulit_integer_constant(eff_sub_con,

   12868             :             }  /* if */

   12871             :       }  /* if */

   13245             : an_opname_kind simple_opname_kind_for_compound_assignment(an_opname_kind kind)
   13246             : /*
   13247             : If kind is some kind of compound assignment, return the opname kind for
   13248             : the corresponding simple operator, e.g., onk_plus_assign ("+=") in produces
   13249             : onk_plus ("+") out.  If kind is not a compound assignment operator,
   13250             : return onk_none.
   13251             : */
   13252             : {
   13253             :   an_opname_kind simple_kind = (an_opname_kind)onk_none;
   13254             : 
   13255             :   switch (kind) {
   13256             :     case onk_plus_assign:
   13257             :       simple_kind = (an_opname_kind)onk_plus;
   13258             :       break;
   13259             :     case onk_minus_assign:
   13260             :       simple_kind = (an_opname_kind)onk_minus;
   13261             :       break;
   13262             :     case onk_times_assign:
   13263             :       simple_kind = (an_opname_kind)onk_star;
   13264             :       break;
   13265             :     case onk_divide_assign:
   13266             :       simple_kind = (an_opname_kind)onk_divide;
   13267             :       break;
   13268             :     case onk_remainder_assign:

   13294      172824 : void do_binary_operation_full(an_expr_operator_kind   op,
   13295             :                               an_operand              *operand_1,
   13296             :                               an_operand              *operand_2,
   13297             :                               a_type_ptr              result_type,
   13298             :                               a_boolean               result_is_lvalue,
   13299             :                               an_operand              *result,
   13300             :                               a_source_position       *operator_position,
   13301             :                               a_token_sequence_number operator_tok_seq_number,
   13302             :                               a_source_position       *operator_position_2)
   13303             : /*
   13304             : Perform a binary operation on 2 operands yielding a result.  op
   13305             : indicates the operation, and operand_1 and operand_2 are the operands.
   13306             : result_type indicates the type of result.  The result is an lvalue if
   13307             : result_is_lvalue is TRUE.  The result is placed in *result.  If the
   13308             : operands are constant, the operation will be folded if possible.
   13309             : operator_position indicates the operator position.  operator_tok_seq_number
   13310             : indicates the token sequence number of the operator.  operator_position_2,
   13311             : if non-NULL, indicates the position of a second operator (e.g., the "]"
   13312             : of a subscript operation).
   13313             : */

   13315      172824 :   a_boolean      did_not_fold, template_constant;
   13316      172824 :   a_boolean      just_past_end;

   13319      172824 :   a_constant_ptr con_1 = local_constant(), con_2 = local_constant();
   13320             : #endif /* GNU_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED */
   13321             : 
   13322      172824 :   if (is_error_operand(operand_1) || is_error_operand(operand_2)) {
   13323           0 :     make_error_operand(result);
   13324             :   } else {
   13325      172824 :     template_constant = expr_stack->prefer_template_constant;
   13326             :     /* Some addressing operations should not be folded in some nonconstant
   13327             :        contexts, because the expression form provides more explicit
   13328             :        addressing information (which is useful for aliasing analysis). */
   13329             :     /* Field-selection operations don't come through this routine, so there's
   13330             :        no point in checking them. */
   13331      172824 :     if (result_is_lvalue) {
   13332             :       /* Can't fold to a constant for an lvalue result. */
   13333             :       try_folding = FALSE;
   13334      171420 :     } else if (template_constant) {
   13335             :       /* Don't fold if we prefer a ck_template_param/tpck_expression

   13538        1301 : static a_boolean expr_has_uncertain_value_category(an_expr_node_ptr expr)
   13539             : /*
   13540             : Sometimes a template-dependent expression can't be known to be an lvalue
   13541             : or an rvalue (e.g., T::x might be an lvalue if x is a static data member,
   13542             : or an rvalue if x is an enumerator).  Return TRUE if the value category
   13543             : of the given expression is uncertain.  The safe answer is TRUE.
   13544             : An error node is considered to have uncertain value category even
   13545             : outside of a template-dependent context.
   13546             : */
   13547             : {
   13548        1301 :   a_boolean uncertain = FALSE;
   13549             : 
   13550        1301 :   if (is_error_node(expr) || is_error_type(expr->type)) {
   13551             :     uncertain = TRUE;
   13552        1301 :   } else if (is_template_dependent_type(expr->type)) {
   13553        1185 :     uncertain = TRUE;
   13554             :     /* In some cases, we can tell that something is really an lvalue or
   13555             :        rvalue based on the operator. */

   13557        1185 :       an_expr_node_ptr op1 = expr->variant.operation.operands;
   13558        1185 :       switch (expr->variant.operation.kind) {
   13559           0 :         case eok_ref_indirect:
   13560             :           /* A reference indirection always produces an lvalue. */
   13561           0 :           uncertain = FALSE;
   13562           0 :           break;
   13563           3 :         case eok_indirect:
   13564           3 :           if (is_pointer_type(op1->type)) {
   13565             :             /* A "*" returns an lvalue unless it's overloaded. */
   13566           0 :             uncertain = FALSE;
   13567             :           }  /* if */
   13568             :           break;
   13569           0 :         case eok_lvalue:
   13570             :           /* An eok_lvalue produces an lvalue by definition. */
   13571           0 :           uncertain = FALSE;
   13572           0 :           break;
   13573           0 :         case eok_cast:
   13574           0 :           if (!could_be_dependent_class_type(expr->type) &&
   13575           0 :               !could_be_dependent_class_type(op1->type) &&
   13576           0 :               !is_error_type(op1->type)) {
   13577             :             /* Casts other than those involving unknown dependent classes
   13578             :                have known value categories. */
   13579           0 :             uncertain = FALSE;
   13580             :           }  /* if */
   13581             :           break;
   13582             :         default:
   13583             :           break;

   13628       80848 : static void do_generic_operand_transformations(an_operand *operand,
   13629             :                                                a_boolean  force_to_rvalue)
   13630             : /*
   13631             : Do transformations that are appropriate on a generic operand, i.e.,
   13632             : an operand in a template-dependent operation, where we can't tell
   13633             : what will be done with the operand.  In particular, we can't tell whether
   13634             : it will be used as an rvalue or an lvalue, unless force_to_rvalue is TRUE,
   13635             : in which case we force the operand to be an rvalue.
   13636             : */

   13683       79780 : void prep_generic_operand_full(an_operand *operand,

   13685             :                                a_boolean  rvalue_expected)
   13686             : /*
   13687             : The indicated operand is about to be used as the operand of an expression
   13688             : involving template parameter types.  lvalue_expected is TRUE to indicate
   13689             : that an lvalue is expected/required, and rvalue_expected is TRUE to indicate
   13690             : that an rvalue is expected/required.  If neither is TRUE, any value category
   13691             : is acceptable in the context where the expression will be used.  An eok_lvalue
   13692             : node will be inserted if necessary to adjust the value category of the
   13693             : expression.
   13694             : */
   13695             : {
   13696       79780 :   an_expr_node_ptr expr;
   13697       79780 :   an_operand       orig_operand;
   13698             : 
   13699       79780 :   check_assertion(is_template_dependent_context());

   13704             :       /* Record that this particular name was referenced in a dependent

   13706             :          unreferenced but might be chosen by a dependent call. */
